column1: Pfizer vaccine available for over 60s in WA from next week, Mark McGowan announces
column2: West Australians aged 60 and older will be eligible to receive the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine from Monday next week, the Premier says.

column1: 'Not very pretty': Whale carcass to be recovered by SA Museum as big 'stench' heats up
column2: The smelly carcass of a rare whale, which has been mauled by sharks and left to rot on a northern Adelaide beach, will be cut up and removed by SA Museum staff and the local council.

column1: ACT lockdown extended for a month, as territory records 22 new COVID-19 cases
column2: The ACT will remain in lockdown for another four weeks amid persistent new case numbers in the community.

column1: NSW records 1,127 COVID-19 cases, two deaths
column2: Deputy health officer Jeremy McAnulty says it is too early to tell if the drop in case numbers means the state is over the highest peak of the Delta outbreak as NSW records 1,127 new COVID-19 cases.

column1: AIS vaccination hub booking error results in hundreds of rescheduled appointments, late-night doses administered
column2: More than 600 Canberrans have their COVID-19 vaccination appointments rescheduled after an overbooking error occurred at the AIS mass vaccination hub.

column1: Could Lawn Hill mine be site of next Juukan Gorge tragedy?
column2: The fallout over the destruction of Western Australia's Juukan Gorge rock shelters is being felt at another mine in Queensland, where a group of Indigenous elders is trying to stop the proposed excavation around a sacred site.

column1: Wild 'de-extinction' plan aims to bring woolly mammoths back to life
column2: Genetics company Colossal secures funding to create an "elephant-mammoth hybrid", saying its technology has the potential to bring back ancient extinct species and restore damaged or lost ecosystems.

column1: 'Limb-threatening' injuries after massive brawl involving 40 armed men in Brisbane's south
column2: Queensland police investigate a brawl involving 40 men armed with bats and poles in a southern Brisbane suburb last night.

column1: Amy spends up to $20,000 a year on magnetic therapy to treat depression. Medicare changes won't help her
column2: After years of lobbying, Medicare will soon partly fund repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation to treat severe depression. But existing patients won't see a cent.

column1: Regional supermarket operator accused of 'systematic' wage theft of more than $1m
column2: South Australia's shop workers union alleges the operator of 20 regional Foodland and IGA supermarkets owes at least 64 workers more than $1 million in unpaid wages, launching a claim in the Federal Court.

column1: Citizenship rules change: Wallabies' Quade Cooper can become an Australian at last
column2: The Immigration Minister changes residency rule for "distinguished" applicants for citizenship to become Australians, after a Wallabies rugby star was rejected multiple times.

column1: US Secretary of State defends chaotic Afghan withdrawal, blames Trump deal
column2: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken pushes against harsh criticism, saying the Biden administration inherited a deal with the Taliban to end the war but no plan for carrying it out.

column1: Melbourne man who died of COVID-19 at home had not been tested, health officials say
column2: A man in his 20s and a woman in her 80s become the fifth and sixth people to die from COVID-19 during Victoria's Delta outbreak. The state has recorded 445 new local infections overnight.

column1: Decade-long ban for Algerian judoka's Olympic withdrawal
column2: Fethi Nourine's decision to pull out of the Tokyo Olympics judo competition because of the possibility he might face an Israeli opponent all but ends the Algerian judoka's career, after his actions draw a 10-year ban.

column1: Authorities praise families, contact tracers as one new COVID case detected in Queensland
column2: Chief Health Officer Jeannette Young says she thinks Brisbane's latest COVID-19 outbreak has been brought under control after a 15-year-old girl who attends St Thomas More College at Sunnybank tests positive.

column1: Prince Andrew challenges a US court's jurisdiction in sex abuse lawsuit
column2: Prince Andrew argues a US court does not have jurisdiction over a lawsuit filed by a woman who claims he abused her at Ghislaine Maxwell's home and Jeffrey Epstein's island.

column1: We fact checked Immigration Minister Alex Hawke on refugee resettlement. Here's what we found
column2: Immigration Minister Alex Hawke says Australia ranks around third globally every year in the amount of refugees it resettles. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

column1: At 62, Ross watched a TV show and decided to go for his first run. It went for 10 hours
column2: Eight years and nine ultramarathons later, the 70-year-old endurance runner is eyeing off a 120km challenge.

column1: Shipping costs have risen by hundreds of millions of dollars and you may be about to pay for it
column2: The competition regulator is investigating a dramatic surge in fees and charges imposed by port operators on trucking firms to load and unload cargo. ACCC chief Rod Sims believes the higher charges are being passed onto consumers in the form of higher prices.

column1: ASX slips, as NAB says business confidence is improving on 'vaccine rollout'
column2: Australian shares fall in morning trade, following a mixed performance on Wall Street as investors focused on potential corporate tax hikes in the United States and upcoming economic data.

column1: Unlawful force used in 'disturbing' arrest shows need for better cultural training of police: lawyer
column2: There are renewed calls for greater training of police in Aboriginal towns after a court found officers used unlawful force during the arrest of an elderly Indigenous man.

column1: Aboriginal health workers fighting COVID vaccine misinformation
column2: In the Northern Territory's remote community of Yarralin there's a new push from the local Aboriginal health service to get residents vaccinated. While progress has been slow, despite door-knocking and community cook-ups, residents and health workers are determined to get their community protected.

column1: Crown floats mandatory vaccination policy for both staff and customers
column2: The resort and casino operator says it is consulting with staff about a mandatory vaccination policy for its 20,000 workers. Unvaccinated people would also be banned from visiting its venues.

column1: Demand on Queensland's public hospital emergency departments outstripping population growth
column2: A Queensland Audit Office report says demand for emergency departments is growing at a faster rate than population growth, and more people are presenting at EDs with complex issues.

column1: 'Please come forward': Rene Latimore's family say they're searching for answers
column2: Katie Marchetti is already living with the agony of losing a sister Rene in a suspected homicide but she fears the "worst is yet to come". She is urging anyone with information, no matter how small, to contact police.

column1: 'Close to not having an arm': Killick Beach shark attack survivor makes slow recovery
column2: Two months and eight surgeries later, great white shark attack survivor Joe Hoffman is on a long road to recovery after his near-fatal encounter on the Mid North Coast.

column1: Queensland MPs give emotional speeches ahead of vote to legalise voluntary assisted dying
column2: Queensland MPs fight back tears, detail personal stories and reveal the "exhausting" experience of weighing up opposing views ahead of a vote on proposed laws to legalise voluntary assisted dying in Queensland.

column1: WA misses out on extra AFL grand final tickets as Bulldogs allocation sells out in hours
column2: Hopes of additional WA tickets have been dashed after the Western Bulldogs fans quickly snapped up the 12,000 AFL grand final tickets allocated to them.

column1: House prices jumped $52,600 in three months, and the RBA says it can't do much about it
column2: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe says he understands concerns about rapid house price growth, but it's helping household wealth to grow.

column1: Mystery donors pay some of Christian Porter's legal fees
column2: Former attorney-general Christian Porter tells federal parliament anonymous donors have covered some of the legal fees he racked up during his defamation case against the ABC, and says he has no way of finding out who they are.

column1: 'They fall into our trap': WA Police pose as drug suppliers to infiltrate organised crime gangs
column2: WA Police say they posed as international drug suppliers to infiltrate local organised crime gangs, resulting in the seizure of more than 30 kilograms of heroin and methylamphetamine and $7 million in cash.

column1: ‘Exciting development': DNA water testing hoped to stop cane toads gaining foothold on Kimberley islands
column2: In the past decade cane toads have marched across most of the Kimberley, so protecting animals on island sanctuaries is now a key priority.

column1: Perth sibling murder accused asked grandmother for shovel after neighbour heard muffled scream from apartment
column2: The grandmother of a man accused of murdering a brother and sister in Victoria Park told police he was bloodied and crying after she picked him up from an apartment complex where the bodies were later found, a court hears.

column1: 'Held hostage in their own homes': People forced to stay in isolation long after 14-day period
column2: A staff member at a public health call centre in a Sydney hotspot area says people in isolation after testing positive for COVID are being trapped at home for weeks after the standard 14-day period because of paperwork delays.

column1: 'I come from a lockdown under': T-shirt design competition relieves the stress
column2: When James Valentine posed the question "if you could sum up this lockdown in one sketch or design, what would it look like?" Sydney responded. And you can now wear it.

column1: Boy and mother with COVID-19 transferred from Broken Hill to Adelaide hospital
column2: A boy sick with COVID-19 is flown to Adelaide for treatment, accompanied by his mother, who also has the virus.

column1: NSW Premier in 'heated' meeting with mayors from Sydney's COVID hotspots
column2: Gladys Berejiklian's meeting with 12 mayors from Sydney's COVID hotspots becomes "a little bit heated" when the topic turns to discrimination.

column1: Hope, empowerment and a Balenciaga shadow on the Met Gala red carpet
column2: The highlight of the fashion year returns with stars switching out their sweatpants for elaborate and sometimes outlandish outfits.

column1: Federal Court judge orders minister to explain 'sudden' $21m Beetaloo Basin fracking grant agreement
column2: A Federal Court judge says he is "concerned" by Federal Resources and Water Minister Keith Pitt's handling of a $21 million grant agreement with a gas company eyeing the Northern Territory's Beetaloo Basin.

column1: Farmer escapes strawberry jam by making 25,000 jars of strawberry jam
column2: With no-one around to do the plucking on his pick-your-own farm, Anthony Sarks's crop looked bound for the back paddock. But he simply couldn't bring himself to waste the fruit.

column1: Albanese tells dumped Labor candidate not to be discouraged by Keneally seat swap
column2: Labor hopeful Tu Le is told not to be deterred from politics, after her candidacy was derailed by senior Labor figure Kristina Keneally being parachuted into her electorate.

column1: Political inquiry warns abuse of female journalists on social media poses threat to democracy
column2: Social media giants must do more to eliminate fake accounts and political parties must establish an online code of conduct, a multi-party Victorian parliamentary inquiry recommends, warning harassment of journalists represents a threat to democratic elections.

column1: Body modifier with no medical qualifications was 'very convincing' before woman ended up in hospital, court told
column2: A woman who had a procedure performed by body modifier Brendan Russell tells a Sydney court she felt she was in "really good hands" and doesn't recall being informed of all the associated risks.

column1: Battery discovery could propel EVs from Sydney to Melbourne on one charge
column2: Australian researchers say they've opened the path to a new generation of batteries that could allow an electric vehicle to drive from Melbourne to Sydney on a single charge.

column1: Israeli boy orphaned by Italian cable car crash allegedly kidnapped amid custody battle
column2: Italian relatives of six-year-old Eitan Biran, who was the sole survivor of a cable car crash earlier this year, allege he has been taken to Israel by his grandfather without their permission.

column1: 'Her victory takes her way beyond tennis and sport': Raducanu tipped for earnings windfall
column2: Emma Raducanu is an instant millionaire after her stunning US Open win, but her rapid emergence, youth and background are all leading sports marketers to predict much bigger off-court earnings.

column1: How are we going to get to 80 per cent vaccinated? Here's what some experts think
column2: Health authorities say getting an extra 10 per cent of people on board to reach 80 per cent vaccination rates is going to be a challenge. This is what experts think will help.

column1: British diplomat draws attention to removal of Chinese mosque minarets
column2: Changes to the nation's mosques come amid an ongoing crackdown on Muslims and other faith communities under the ruling Chinese Communist Party's "Sinicisation" of religion.

column1: We’re back to record property price growth, so what’s being done about it?
column2: Officials from Treasury and the Reserve Bank front a parliamentary committee to wrestle with what is driving record property price growth and what can be done about it.

column1: Inside inner-city Sydney's latest COVID-19 battleground
column2: The inner-city Sydney suburbs of Glebe, Redfern and Waterloo have been flagged as new areas of concern — and all have high populations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents.

column1: First dose COVID vaccination rates in inner Darwin and Palmerston jump by 10 per cent in two weeks, new data shows
column2: New Australian government data shows first dose COVID-19 vaccination rates have shot past 90 per cent in Darwin's CBD and inner suburbs, but rates are still progressing at a crawl in some remote parts of the NT.

column1: Dozens of 'liquid gold' vaccine appointments vacant at Queensland Health hubs
column2: Data finds dozens of appointments at Queensland Health vaccination hubs and clinics are still vacant the day before, despite the push to increase the state's slow inoculation rates.

column1: For you, this house may cost $500k. For Habib, it's $546,000
column2: Buying a house in Hobart right now is hard. For Habib ur Rehman, it's even worse. That's because migrants face an 8 per cent surcharge on the cost of a home.

column1: A sixth of NSW Health staff 'completely unvaccinated'
column2: One in six NSW Health staff are yet to have their first COVID-19 jab, despite a looming mandatory vaccination deadline, according to documents submitted to state Parliament.

column1: Booker Prize shortlist: Americans dominate, one author makes history
column2: Nadifa Mohamed is the first British-Somali author to be shortlisted for the Booker Prize, joining a Pulitzer Prize winner and a first-time novelist, while big name authors Kazuo Ishiguro and Rachel Cusk miss out.

column1: Will everyone need a COVID booster shot? Here's what we do (and don't) know
column2: There's still a lot to learn about COVID-19 booster vaccines. And then there's the billions of people globally who haven't received their first jab.

column1: Last year we were all in it together. This year COVID demands an agonising choice
column2: Economics is called the dismal science in part because it is about hard choices — situations where we can't have our cake and eat it too. We're about to see a lot more of them when it comes to COVID, writes Peter Martin

column1: Online activity during COVID lockdowns sees surge in cyber attacks
column2: A cybercrime is now reported every eight minutes in Australia with criminals and spies taking advantage of large numbers of people working from home during COVID-19 lockdowns.

column1: Stranded Adelaide couple plead for health authorities to let them come home
column2: A young Adelaide couple stranded in Broken Hill are pleading for SA Health to let them cross the border after their camping trip took a turn for the worse.

column1: Trent Cotchin steps down as Richmond captain
column2: Cotchin will play on in 2022 but is handing over the reins following a decorated stint as Tigers captain, which includes three premierships.

column1: Roosters hit with finals blow as Sam Verrills receives two-match suspension
column2: Sam Verrills will only play again this season if the Sydney Roosters qualify for the NRL grand final, after the judiciary upholds his grade-two careless high tackle charge.

column1: The new freedoms given to NSW aged care facilities and why some may not use them
column2: After suffering through nearly 12 weeks of another strict set of COVID-19 lockdown orders, some freedoms are being returned to aged care residents in NSW.

column1: Inquiry shown video of 'extreme' bushfire tornado that flipped a fire truck, killing volunteer Samuel McPaul
column2: An inquiry hears how a fire tornado sucked smoke and flames six kilometres into the air into a whirling ball, created winds of more than 320 kilometres an hour and flipped a 10-tonne fire truck.

column1: Rare raptors hatch but others fall prey to a fox in overnight raid
column2: Cameras show the vagaries of life for rare osprey chicks with two hatching successfully while two others are snatched by a fox.

column1: Rabbitohs brimming with confidence as they eye off first premiership in seven years
column2: The Rabbitohs, who are one win away from advancing to the grand final, feel they have the self-belief to claim the NRL premiership after beating the Panthers in the opening week of the play-offs.

column1: It takes a village: Ungarie community turns town hall into post office after death of local postmaster
column2: Residents in a regional NSW town take on the postal run after the death of the much-loved local postmaster.

column1: 'They've cruelled this town': Border businesses say support package 'too late' to save some
column2: Despite fresh funding support for struggling businesses on the southern Gold Coast, many people fear it might be too late for some traders.
column3: Cathy Border, Alexandria Utting, and Tara Cassidy

column1: AFL greats named to present premiership cup to winning team on grand final day
column2: Garry Lyon will hand over the cup to the Demons if they win the grand final in Perth, while Chris Grant will have the honour if the Bulldogs win the season decider.
column3: Cathy Border, Alexandria Utting, and Tara Cassidy

column1: In pictures: How the world's sporting stars stole the spotlight at the Met Gala
column2: They may have been sporting some unfamiliar gear, but some of the world's top athletes were rubbing shoulders with the sartorial elite at one of the most extravagant events on the celebrity calendar.

column1: Snow industry on brink of collapse after second winter without trade
column2: Industry experts and retailers are concerned Australia's snow industry may not make it through to next year without significant aid from the state and federal governments, following a second winter without trade.

column1: 'Fire, explosions, rockfalls are recurring — why?': Mine safety expert warns against complacency
column2: There have been nine people killed in Queensland mining incidents since July 2018. Mine safety expert professor David Cliff says managing risks in the industry is complex.

column1: Disability carer's assaults only uncovered because father checked security vision on phone
column2: The family of a man with a disability who was assaulted by his carer said it took him six months to smile again after the incident, which was captured on home security footage.

column1: Star jockey Jamie Kah facing longer ban after misleading stewards about COVID breach
column2: Kah may be banned for up to five months after being found guilty of "wilfully" omitting details about a much-publicised gathering in Mornington, which was a breach of Victoria's lockdown protocols.

column1: SA teacher cries as she apologises for grooming high school student for sex
column2: Renee Underwood fronts the District Court charged with making a child amenable to sexual activity after earlier pleading guilty to the crime.

column1: Two teen survivors of Launceston nurse sue health system
column2: Two teenage girls who were allegedly groomed and sexually abused by James Geoffrey Griffin sue the Tasmanian Health Service for failing to investigate the numerous complaints against him.

column1: Third Big Bird bandit appears in court, bail curfew varied to allow work in hotel

column1: Brisbane school students tested for COVID-19 after allegedly mixing with locked-down teenagers

column1: Curtin University lobbies for retraction of unethical AI study on Uyghur facial recognition
column2: An Australian university implicated in unethical research using facial recognition technology to identify Uyghur and Tibetan minorities unsuccessfully lobbies for it to be retracted by publishers on multiple attempts.

column1: A dispute over $30 fuels axe assault on grandmother, court hears
column2: A 30-year-old man, who threatened a woman at a Mount Gambier park with a tomahawk axe over a $30 dispute, has received a six-month suspended sentence.

column1: Gold medalist Ariarne Titmus receives superstar reception on hometown visit
column2: Olympic medalist Ariarne Titmus returns to Launceston to inspire the next generation of elite swimmers.

column1: What happened to Gulf Livestock 1? Questions remain unanswered a year on from sunken live export ship
column2: It has been 12 months since a live export ship sank off the Japanese coast, but a number of details about the tragedy remain a mystery.

column1: 'He pushed me': Aged care resident identified alleged killer before death, court hears
column2: A Canberra man accused of pushing a fellow nursing home resident, who broke her hip and later died from complications, stands trial in the ACT Supreme Court after pleading not guilty to manslaughter.

column1: 'I've never seen such a tight margin': Just two votes decide Alice Springs Mayor
column2: The Northern Territory Electoral Commissioner says he has never seen such a narrow result for such a high profile position, after the Alice Springs mayoral race was won by just two votes.
column3: Stewart Brash, Mitchell Abram, and Emma Haskin

column1: Port Adelaide confirms interest in want-away Swan, open to move for GWS forward Jeremy Finlayson
column2: Port Adelaide confirms it has interest in want-away Swan Jordan Dawson, as pressure continues to grow on head coach Ken Hinkley.

column1: Mark McGowan's warning that SA 'may regret' border reopening prompts rebuke from Steven Marshall
column2: SA Premier Steven Marshall's decision to reopen borders to the eastern states once vaccination targets are reached could see the state's western border slammed shut, WA Premier Mark McGowan warns.

column1: Endangered fly with 'legs for days' named after drag queen RuPaul

column1: Fugitive on run for 30 years hands himself into police because life will be 'much easier' in prison
column2: Darko Desic, who broke out of Grafton jail 30 years ago, decides life will be "much easier" if he is behind bars again after the pandemic stripped him of work and left him homeless.

column1: 18yo man granted bail over alleged 'severe' group attack involving metal bat that left boy on life support
column2: The court was told police received an audio recording from the elevator in the building, which allegedly depicts the group "celebrating" after the alleged assault and referring to the child as "dead".

column1: Mice breeding fast for another plague after short winter respite
column2: Experts have significant concerns about the plague exploding again with mouse numbers reported in Queensland, NSW, Victoria and WA.

column1: Stoush brewing after regions abolished in planned overhaul of WA's 'broken' electoral system
column2: The McGowan Government endorses new rules which critics say will diminish the voice of the regions in State Parliament.

column1: Man dead after three-vehicle crash on Barton Highway
column2: Police confirm a man has died after a multi-vehicle collision on the Barton Highway in Canberra earlier today.

column1: California's recall election results are in: Newsom stays
column2: California Governor Gavin Newsom defeats an attempt to remove him from office, a move coming from disapproval of his pandemic policies.

column1: COVID-19 blamed for design delays on army's troubled $5b Boxer vehicles
column2: After first denying its largest-ever weapons project had a problem, Defence now says its Boxer fleet faces a 12-month delay.

column1: It's official — the flu did 'basically disappear' this year
column2: Before COVID-19 arrived, the number of influenza cases was soaring above 300,000. This year, there were less than 500.

column1: Alfred Hospital, Ballarat building sites among latest on COVID-19 exposure list
column2: New tier 1 COVID-19 exposure sites have been identified at The Alfred Hospital and building sites in Ballarat suburbs.

column1: He's saved over 60,000 lives. Some want to stop him
column2: Oscar Camps was a lifeguard on the calm beaches of Barcelona. Then in a single day he saved more lives than in an entire career.

column1: Former disability carer fined $15,000 over incident that left man with life-threatening injuries
column2: A former disability carer has been fined for breaching workplace health and safety laws over an incident that left a man with injuries that almost killed him.

column1: Children under 12 share their concerns as Australia attempts to open up without them vaccinated
column2: Australia's COVID-19 vaccination rollout is now in its next phase with 12 to 15-year-olds eligible for Pfizer, but younger children say they are worried they are not safe.

column1: Why Sydney's COVID-19 lockdown could end a week early for fully vaccinated people
column2: An ABC analysis shows NSW could reach its target of fully vaccinating 70 per cent of its population aged 16 and above as early as October 8 — something that would see its COVID-19 lockdown lifted a week ahead of schedule.

column1: With just two ways to flee Afghanistan, this is what it's like at one exit
column2: With the Taliban's flag flying over Afghanistan once again, there are only a handful of ways to slip out of the country. Those who make the treacherous journey to Torkham on the border must talk their way into Pakistan.

column1: As Australia burned, the oceans bloomed with algae feeding on the ashes
column2: Iron-rich ash and smoke from the Black Summer bushfires dropped from the atmosphere into the Southern Ocean, fuelling enormous blooms of algae between New Zealand and South America.

column1: Porter's 'blind trust' leaves more questions for Morrison to answer
column2: Porter's "disclosure" has raised far more questions than it has answered. It's created all-new political problems for the Morrison Government too, writes David Speers.

column1: The stories of Australia's unemployment crisis: 'I noticed a decline the minute I turned 50'
column2: Finding work after being made redundant can already be a soul-destroying process — but it becomes crippling when you're facing further hurdles outside your control.

column1: Would you take a pay cut to keep working from home?
column2: Working from home is here to stay long after the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the federal government's key economic adviser, with a new report suggesting some people might even take a pay cut to remain in their home office.

column1: Australia to get nuclear-powered submarines, scrap $90b plan to build French-designed subs
column2: The ABC understands Australia will use American and British technology to configure its next submarine fleet in a bid to replace its existing Collins class subs with a boat more suitable to the deteriorating strategic environment.
column3: Andrew Probyn, Stephen Dziedzic, and Andrew Greene

column1: These foreign-owned retailers received millions in JobKeeper and doubled their profits
column2: Two of Australia's most recognisable retailers doubled their profits after claiming JobKeeper, new figures reveal.

column1: Judge awards parents $125k for birth of seventh child after failed sterilisation procedure
column2: A WA woman who gave birth to her seventh child after a failed sterilisation procedure is awarded $125,000, which includes less than $90,000 for raising the boy.

column1: TGA threatens Craig Kelly with legal action over 'seriously misleading' COVID texts
column2: The nation's medical regulator demands rogue crossbencher Craig Kelly stop distributing "seriously misleading" information about COVID-19 vaccines.

column1: Property value evidence thrown out in windfarm court battle
column2: Two men are seeking damages from the Bald Hills Wind Farm in Victoria's south-east, claiming it has affected land prices while turbine noise is also a nuisance.

column1: Growing dissatisfaction with federal politics sees Coalition seats under threat from independents
column2: The next federal election is set to see a new wave of independents fight for safe Coalition seats, as discontent with the major political parties grows.

column1: WA's South West lives up to its 'seismically active' reputation
column2: Scientists have recorded more than 1,100 earthquakes in Western Australia's South West over a recent eight-month period.

column1: Inmates sue NT government and Correctional Services over treatment after Darwin prison riot
column2: Two prisoners allegedly involved in a riot at the Darwin Correctional Centre last year commence legal action, claiming they were subjected to assault, battery and false imprisonment in the aftermath.

column1: Shepparton locals share a message of hope as Ballarat prepares to re-enter lockdown
column2: For weeks, it's been quiet on the streets of Shepparton, but now that's about to change – much to the relief of its residents.

column1: Can the Wallabies win consecutive Tests for the first time in two seasons?
column2: The Wallabies took on the physical Springboks and won last weekend on the Gold Coast. The challenge this Saturday is to do something they’re yet to achieve under coach Dave Rennie — win back-to-back Test matches, writes Brett McKay.

column1: BOM says La Niña's now an even chance to reign again this summer
column2: It's looking like a cool, wet summer — again — for much of the country with a good chance of the return of La Niña, amid other key indicators, say forecasters.

column1: Ex-partner of former minister Adam Brooks gets extension of interim family violence order
column2: Adam Brooks' ex-partner has been granted an extension of an interim family violence order against him. In court, the woman alleged the former politician stalked and harassed her and entered her home without permission.

column1: Drivers are challenging Victoria's electric vehicle tax, arguing it may be unconstitutional
column2: Electric vehicle owners are taking action in the High Court against a levy introduced by the Victorian government.

column1: Roosters put faith in rookie hooker for NRL semi-final clash with Sea Eagles
column2: Sydney Roosters coach Trent Robinson backs reserve grade hooker Ben Marschke to be up to the task in Friday night's semi-final.

column1: Northern Australia Minister David Littleproud criticises NT's stage 3 roadmap
column2: Federal Northern Australia Minister David Littleproud says the Northern Territory government's decision to launch its own stage 3 COVID roadmap adds to inconsistency across the country.

column1: Memory lapse or new nickname? Joe Biden calls Scott Morrison 'that fella Down Under'
column2: It might have been an awkward fumble or just a term of endearment, but having Joe Biden give Scott Morrison a new name is not the most embarrassing thing that's happened to an Australian leader in the US.

column1: 'When a vet tells me to vaccinate a horse, I vaccinate a horse': Victorian racing industry to mandate COVID-19 vaccine for staff
column2: Horse racing spectators are not yet required to be vaccinated to attend races despite an industry-wide mandate to all staff to be vaccinated by the end of November.
column3: Emma Field, Shannon Schubert, and Kimberley Price

column1: Immigration Minister to issue further bridging visas to Biloela Tamil family
column2: An Australian government barrister says the Immigration Minister intends to issue further three-month bridging visas to Priya, Nades, and Kopika Muruguppan next Thursday.

column1: Taiwan plans $11 billion boost in defence spending as it warns of 'severe threat' from China
column2: Taiwan's government is proposing extra defence spending over the next five years, warning of an urgent need to upgrade the nation's weapons in the face of a "severe threat" from neighbouring China.

column1: Targa rally report into triple fatality calls for speeds to be reined in to avoid 'further deaths'
column2: A report into three deaths during the Targa Tasmania rally earlier this year makes recommendations including dramatic changes to the route and warns the cost of the race will rise significantly.

column1: How Victoria's COVID restrictions will change this weekend
column2: There are slight changes to COVID restrictions for Victorians on the way. Here are the changes coming into effect from 11:59pm Friday.

column1: Former sex worker choked and threatened to kill MP after long-term relationship, court told
column2: A former Perth sex worker allegedly choked and threatened to kill an ex-politician with whom she had a long term relationship, a Perth court is told.

column1: Morrison has gone nuclear — and there's no turning back
column2: The geostrategic wrestle between Washington and Beijing is one for the ages and Australia is now to play an even bigger role — in a stealthier and speedier bit of nuclear kit, writes Andrew Probyn.

column1: Doctor in jail on attempted murder charges banned from practising medicine for the rest of his life
column2: A doctor who is serving a prison sentence for the attempted murder of a pharmacist has been banned from practising for the rest of his life, in the longest sanction ever imposed in Australia.

column1: Murray border communities plead to be treated as one

column1: Third man charged over shooting death of country club owner
column2: Logan man Ashton McKinley is the third man to be charged over the shooting murder of a 64-year-old country club owner on Queensland's Fraser Coast during an alleged burglary last month.

column1: The arguments behind the religious vaccine signs spotted at protests
column2: No major religions in Australia expressly prohibit vaccination, but that doesn’t mean religion doesn’t inform some people’s decision on whether to get a COVID-19 jab.

column1: 'BFF theatre' puts Australia in tricky position between US and China
column2: There are big, enduring questions hanging over the announcement of a new strategic alliance between Australia, the UK and US — and they go to the heart of Australia's sovereign capability, writes Laura Tingle.

column1: Detained Huawei executive reaches deal with US prosecutors

column1: Andrew Cuomo's brother accused of historical sexual harassment of news executive
column2: Shelley Ross accuses Chris Cuomo in a New York Times opinion piece of squeezing her buttocks at a 2005 party in front of her husband.

column1: 'I'd be putting my hand up': Clarkson considers prospect of coaching a Tasmanian AFL team
column2: Four-time premiership coach Alastair Clarkson expresses interest in being in charge of a Tasmanian club, should the AFL give the state its own team.

column1: SA woman accused of threatening police during guns audit remanded in custody

column1: 'It is gunshots, ma'am': Triple zero calls played in Darwin CBD shooting trial

column1: Former ICAC chief 'horrified' by changes to SA's anti-corruption watchdog
column2: The debate continues around South Australia's Independent Commissioner Against Corruption following sweeping changes passed in Parliament.

column1: One of Australia's longest-running native title claims now over

column1: Green, Marsh post Sheffield Shield centuries as jostling for Ashes berths heats up
column2: With the men's Ashes on the horizon, Test all-rounder Cameron Green impresses for Western Australia, while veteran Shaun Marsh also shows solid form with the bat.

column1: Jailbreak shines light on mass incarceration of Palestinians

column1: Pfizer promises to deliver Australia's full October quota despite global distribution problems

column2: After a horrific ordeal in hospital with COVID-19, construction worker Nathan Chellia rues not getting vaccinated and pleas with protesting tradies to learn from his mistakes.

column1: 'Discrimination in the womb': UK woman with Down syndrome loses fight against abortion laws

column2: The crowd is building at Perth Stadium, as the countdown is on to this year's grand final. Will Melbourne break the drought, or will the sons of the West win in the west? Follow our AFL grand final live blog.

column1: Former police officer convicted of George Floyd's murder launches appeal against conviction
column2: Derek Chauvin, who knelt on George Floyd's neck for more than nine minutes as he lay on the ground pleading for air, files documents showing he intends to appeal against his conviction and senten

column1: Dominic Perrottet set to be new Premier of NSW

column2: Queensland Health declares Gate 24 at Brisbane's domestic airport a close contact exposure site after an infectious person was there on Saturday.

column1: England names 'strongest available squad' for Ashes tour
column2: Despite the likes of Ben Stokes and Jofra Archer being ruled out, England is confident captain Joe Root has an experienced squad under his leadership for the upcoming men's Ashes series.

column1: Gypsy King Tyson Fury reigns supreme over heavyweight division
column2: Tyson Fury has confirmed his dominance over the heavyweight division after his sensational knockout victory over Deontay Wilder. Next stop for the Gypsy King? The undisputed crown.

column1: Plane crashes in central Russia, killing 16 people
column2: Russian news agencies are reporting that a Let L-410 Turbolet plane carrying a group of parachute jumpers crashed near a city in Russia's Tatarstan region killing 16 people and injuring seven.

column1: Impressive Aussies defeat India in final T20 international
column2: Australia completes its multi-format series against India with a 14-run victory in the third Twenty20 international on the Gold Coast.

column1: NT says it won't wait for 'abysmally low' remote vax rates to improve before reopening
column2: The NT's Health Minister says the plan to reopen will not be delayed despite deep concerns about vaccination rates in vulnerable communities — and a dispute about the figures overall.

column1: More police testify in murder trial of officer who shot woman on suburban street
column2: The most junior officer at the scene of the death of an  Aboriginal woman — known as JC — said he only wielded his taser in the confrontation. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains an image of a person who has died.

column1: Accused AFL grand final COVID breachers, who allegedly faked documents, to face Darwin court
column2: Two Melbourne men accused of falsifying documents to enter WA to attend the AFL grand final are ordered to face court in the Northern Territory.

column1: Western Sydney residents enjoy freedoms after months of harshest lockdown restrictions
column2: After months of harsh restrictions, many in Western Sydney were keen for some retail therapy, waiting in line as shops reopened on the stroke of midnight.

column1: 'Increasingly interested': Taliban scrutinise departing Australians and permanent residents from Afghanistan
column2: A parliamentary hearing in Canberra reveals that more than 280 Australian citizens or permanent residents remain stranded in Afghanistan almost two months after the Taliban seized power in Kabul, with around 26,000 Afghans applying for humanitarian visas.

column1: 'There will be pain', but WA Nationals back net zero carbon target
column2: While the federal Nationals remain divided on net zero, the party's WA branch has nailed its colours to the mast and backed a 2050 target.

column1: Dairy, beef industries hatch plan to stop slaughter of unwanted calves
column2: Half of all calves born on Australian dairy farms live less than a month and farmers think there's a better option.

column1: WA's first tropical cyclone could hit before Christmas in earlier than usual cyclone season
column2: It is not just people in WA's north who need to be prepare for cyclones this season, as BoM predicts the damaging windstorms could reach further south once again.

column1: Canberra developer rescinds more contracts for off-the-plan properties, sparking possible law change
column2: Sheridan Burnett purchased an off-the-plan apartment from 3 Property Group's Allegro development. The developer has now pulled out of the deal, leaving Ms Burnett and others like her angry at being left high and dry.
column3: Antoinette Radford, Elizabeth Byrne, and Michael Inman

column1: New technology kept a donated heart healthy for seven hours and transformed Andrew's life
column2: Researchers hope a "heart in a box" system being trialled at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne could lead to a 15 per cent increase in heart transplants in Australia.

column1: Man with 'grandiose ideas' of being head of IS in Australia jailed for seven years
column2: A judge says Sydney man Isaac El Matari "did a lot of talking" and there was a "low" chance of him launching a terrorism attack in Australia, as the 22-year-old is jailed for seven years.

column1: Brisbane Roar young gun reveals he has been battling leukaemia
column2: Exciting Brisbane Roar youngster Izaack Powell reveals on social media he has been battling leukaemia since June.

column1: ‘Sometimes a language is held by one or two people’: Fears for Indigenous culture if COVID spreads
column2: Indigenous artists and major arts organisations join forces to call for special measures to protect First Nations people living in remote communities, fearing the loss of culture if COVID-19 reaches vulnerable people, including Indigenous artists and elders.

column1: 'Very infectious' female miner tests positive for COVID-19 after arriving in SA from Melbourne
column2: A fly-in fly-out mine worker tests positive for COVID-19 after arriving in Adelaide from Melbourne, then going to a hotel in a taxi, with SA Health now urgently seeking to identify close contacts.

column1: Young man cleared of friend's manslaughter at small-town golf club
column2: Dane McLennan has been found not guilty over the 2019 death of his long-time family friend and former neighbour John Durie.

column1: 'Record breaking performances' at GFG's Australian operations help lift international empire out of debt
column2: GFG Alliance's restructuring update reveals strong profits from its Australian operations have helped to repay creditors and secure a funding agreement for Sanjeev Gupta's international empire.

column1: France fights back to win Nations League with late goal from Mbappe
column2: World champions France have won the UEFA Nations League final with a 2-1 comeback victory over Spain in Milan.

column1: The Taliban says US will provide humanitarian aid to Afghanistan
column2: American and Taliban officials have held talks in Doha, with a spokesman for the militant group saying the US will provide aid but is refusing to recognise Afghanistan's new rulers.

column1: SA Health chief pours doubt on Premier's Christmas reopening push
column2: South Australia's top health bureaucrat is distancing himself from a proposal to remove quarantining requirements for fully vaccinated interstate travellers by Christmas, saying such a deadline "hasn't come from me".

column1: NFL player celebrates missed kick, goes on to lose game

column1: Cricket Australia 'likely' to postpone Afghanistan Test
column2: Cricket Australia expects the men's Test in Hobart will be put on hold, as it waits for more clarity from the federal government about the "situation on the ground" in Afghanistan.

column1: Adelaide woman who killed two brothers in crash sentenced to nine years' jail
column2: The sentence given to an Adelaide woman whose "drug-fuelled dangerous driving" killed two "innocent" and much-loved brothers is described as not long enough by some of those closest to them.

column1: Treasury confirms it knew government was paying out billions in JobKeeper to firms that 'may not need support'
column2: Treasury says $27 billion in JobKeeper payments went to businesses whose turnover either increased or did not decline as much as required, but rejects calls to introduce a clawback mechanism and defends the scheme's design.

column1: Hunter records 82 new COVID cases as 'Freedom Day' caution urged
column2: The region is posting some the highest numbers in NSW and business owners, politicians and health officials are reminding people that we're not out of the woods just yet.
column3: Liz Farquhar, Madeline Lewis, and Jenny Marchant

column1: Why did only 407 stranded Queenslanders apply for the home quarantine trial?
column2: Thousands of Queenslanders stranded in interstate hotspots have been invited to take part in a trial allowing them to return and quarantine at home — but with the scheme beginning today, only 407 people have signed up.

column1: Live: NSW Now: Premier Perrottet avoids fine after breaching COVID rules during photo op
column2: MORNING BRIEFING: Premier Dominic Perrottet avoids a fine from NSW Police after he was spotted breaching the public health orders at a media press conference yesterday.

column1: 'The flower of joy and hope': Sunflowers get community sowing
column2: The Liverpool Plains community plants sunflower seeds now in the hope they will be ready for selfies by Christmas and the new year.

column1: Chopper Read described it as a 'madhouse' that 'breeds psychopaths'. Today your kids can play there
column2: When the notorious 150-year-old Pentridge prison closed down in Melbourne, it left a difficult question: what to do with it. It's one that divides opinions and not everyone's happy about what's happening on site.

column1: New tier 1 sites added to Victoria's list of COVID-19 exposure sites
column2: Health authorities list new tier 1 COVID-19 exposure sites overnight in Geelong, Bendigo, Drouin West, and Mooroolbark.

column1: 'Banks believe they are the moral arbiter': Sex industry and gun shops denied financial services, advocates say
column2: Legally operating businesses in the sex, adult and firearms industries say they are being denied services from banks and other financial companies.

column1: 'Fiji instead of Queensland': Aussies are opting for tropical holidays overseas
column2: With Fiji welcoming tourists from a select number of countries, including Australia, the US and New Zealand from November 11, Sydney mother Lisa Thwaite wasted no time in booking an international family vacation, instead of risking interstate border closures with a domestic holiday.

column1: Indian shop assistants finally win the right to sit down, after years of standing up
column2: Unions in India hail a law change allowing retail workers to sit, but warn their fight for better working conditions continues.

column1: Are you a young, aspiring journalist?
column2: ABC News welcomes your ideas that explore the issues young people are facing — and possible solutions — as we find a path forward from the challenges of COVID-19.

column1: Scottish Socceroos lead Australia's World Cup charge
column2: They may know more about haggis than Harold Holt, but Scotland-born Socceroos Harry Souttar and Martin Boyle are leading Australia's charge to the 2022 World Cup.

column1: Anti-pokies lobby urges action as 50-year monopoly nears end in Tasmania
column2: With an almost 50-year monopoly on gambling in Tasmania about to end, critics of the industry say those who are about to frame new laws must "seize upon the opportunity to put in place better harm minimisation measures".

column1: As millions in NSW celebrate freedoms, Bernadette faces six more weeks in lockdown
column2: Thousands of cancer patients and organ transplant recipients will have to wait weeks or even months before they can get a third booster shot that will allow them to enjoy the same freedoms as everyone else.

column1: As Melbourne gears up to exit lockdown, suburbs in the south-east are struggling to curb COVID
column2: The local government area of Casey is recording the most new COVID cases while its rate of fully vaccinated adults falls behind the state average.

column1: COVID vaccine effectiveness is waning. But by how much?
column2: COVID-19 vaccines are working remarkably well to reduce rates of severe disease and death. But a growing number of studies suggest their protection against infection is waning over time.

column1: 'Someone had to pay, and I'm the one that copped it': Fired Sony music exec speaks out

column1: Bulletproof glass and 24-hour surveillance: The life of an American abortion doctor

column1: Iraqi forces capture senior Islamic State finance manager

column1: 'Is that what he says?': Prince Charles urges Scott Morrison and other leaders to attend COP26

column1: 'Immoral and irresponsible': China takes second swipe at former prime minister Tony Abbott's recent comments

column1: Ambulance crash leaves two men dead in central Queensland

column1: How the government plans to help half of kids with mental health issues
column2: A new strategy by the federal government is hoping to cut down lengthy wait times and reduce out-of-pocket costs for professional help for children with mental health issues.

column1: UK police drop investigation into Prince Andrew in Virginia Giuffre case
column2: After a review of evidence relating to sex crime allegations against Prince Andrew and the late US financier Jeffrey Epstein, UK police drops its investigation.

column1: Relative of Hoffmann's alleged murder victim takes the stand

column1: Man spared jail after assaulting attendant on flight from Melbourne to Adelaide
column2: A drunk and disorderly passenger who assaulted a flight attendant and threatened to "smash" another passenger on a Virgin Australia flight has been spared jail.

column1: How to prove your vaccination status as Victoria prepares to reopen

column2: Benjamin Hoffmann’s fourth and final alleged victim sustained 69 injuries across his body, including dozens of “stab or slicing" injuries in a "struggle" that led to his death, a court has heard.

column2: A father is arrested and charged with allegedly breaching SA's COVID-19 directions at a city medi-hotel this afternoon, with his young daughter taken into SA Health's care.

column1: Wildlife officers complete two-year quest to remove tyre from elk's neck

column1: Break-in at heritage-listed hotel has guest hiding in wardrobe

column1: Mitch Marsh eyeing off key role at T20 World Cup

column1: The healthcare sector's plastic addiction is spiralling during COVID. There's a business case for tackling it
column2: Frustrated doctors and nurses workers are speaking out about their sector's reliance on single-use plastics. They're fighting back to save both the environment and money.

column1: Live: NSW Now: Next stage of reopening could arrive next week, Premier says

column1: Queensland coal city 'moving fast' to become global hydrogen hub
column2: Despite the tension within the coalition government about committing to a net-zero carbon target, in the centre of the Queensland coal belt leaders are already planning for a low carbon future.

column1: New tier 1 COVID-19 exposure sites listed in Victoria
column2: Health authorities list new tier 1 COVID-19 exposure sites in Wangaratta, Trafalgar, Kotupna, Bendigo and Torquay.

column1: JobMaker was meant to support 450,000 jobs. The real figure is just 1 per cent of that

column1: Taxpayer-funded $250,000 legal effort helps keep original French submarine price secret
column2: Defence and the French company Naval Group spends almost a quarter of a million dollars on taxpayer-funded lawyers trying to keep hidden the original proposed cost of Australia's future submarine.

column1: It was meant to be here months ago, so when is the Novavax vaccine coming to Australia?
column2: Australia initially expected Novavax to start arriving here in mid-2021, but the vaccine could end up playing a key role in our booster shot program.

column1: Jon thought his solar panels were a good deal. Then he discovered he'd paid double the price
column2: Vulnerable Australians — including pensioners — are being signed up to overpriced solar deals, with some being charged almost double what their system is worth.

column1: What would it cost Australia's poorest state to help a mining magnate launch a hydrogen hub?
column2: Mining magnate Andrew Forrest has pledged to spend "well over" $500 million on a 250-megawatt green hydrogen plant. What hasn't been discussed is how much the plan could cost the state, writes Emily Baker.

column1: An assault left Beth with a broken nose, months later she's still struggling with the trauma
column2: After a violent assault in Melbourne's south-east, Beth was left suffering "severe" anxiety. With Victorian victims of crime waiting up to four years for decisions on their compensation claims, she doesn't know when she'll be able to afford help.

column1: Churches and mosques delay reopening to avoid having to turn away the unvaccinated
column2: Places of worship have been allowed to reopen but many are choosing to wait until NSW reaches 80 per cent fully vaccinated, with religious leaders saying they are uncomfortable with having to tell people they are not welcome.

column1: IBAC vs ICAC: What are these anti-corruption commissions and how do they compare?
column2: What are anti-corruption commissions? How do ICAC in NSW and IBAC in Victoria differ? And why is a federal integrity commission being proposed? Yee-Fui Ng explains.

column1: Victoria may hit its vaccination targets ahead of schedule, but that doesn't mean restrictions will ease earlier

column1: Soaring house prices leave us with three urgent questions. Here's why an inquiry into the problem won't answer them
column2: Never has an inquiry into the skyrocketing price of homes been more urgent. Rarely has one been as ill-suited as the one underway right now, writes Peter Martin.

column1: What's causing this strange radio signal from the centre of the Milky Way?
column2: Astronomers are baffled by a mysterious radio signal coming from near the centre of our galaxy that appears and disappears randomly.

column1: One of the biggest stars in the NBA has been stood down by his team

column1: In this country, you get two power bills: One from the electric company, the other from the 'Mafia'

column1: 'It is pretty serious now': China's property sector wary of Evergrande default

column1: Most Australians support a net zero target via renewables, Australia Institute reveals
column2: As the federal Coalition negotiates a climate policy ahead of the Glasgow COP26 summit, a new report says the majority of Australians support a target to achieve net zero.

column1: Tasmania announces state target of net zero emissions from 2030

column1: Travis Head goes ballistic with record-breaking double century
column2: Travis Head has smashed a stunning 230 off just 127 balls in a devastating knock in the one-day cup for South Australia against Queensland.

column1: Painted amongst the desert spinifex 40 years ago, this art is finally about to be unveiled
column2: 'It is a story with most of the early pages torn out.' Missing artworks to go on display in Adelaide for the first time after decades stashed in a shipping container.

column1: What do you do when you reach 100 years old? Play golf of course

column1: Scathing report says Victoria can't show if, or how, it's halting species decline
column2: The auditor-general says government reporting on biodiversity protection lacks detail and accountability, as about a third of the state's flora and fauna are believed to be facing extinction.

column1: Nurse killed in ambulance crash was a new grandad who touched 'thousands of lives'

column1: Coates rules out IOC pressure on China over human rights ahead of Winter Olympics
column2: With Beijing set to stage the Winter Games early next year, International Olympic Committee vice-president John Coates says the governing body cannot interfere in humanitarian issues in a host country.

column1: 'They say we live in a lucky country. I beg to differ': Inside the Aboriginal housing divide
column2: Aboriginal housing tenants in one regional community are locked in a tense standoff with their local land council over what they describe as years of neglect.

column1: Brother of missing boy heard 'cry for help' after WA waterfall kayaking accident

column3: Kyle Pauletto, Tom Edwards, and John Dobson

column1: 'It will come, it will infect, and it will kill': Stark warning to the COVID unvaccinated in WA
column2: WA's Vaccine Commander issues a 'sobering' message to the unvaccinated, saying COVID-19 can not be kept out of the state, and people will be infected and die.

column1: There were plenty of fireworks as SA experienced its own 'Independents' Day': Here's how it unfolded
column2: This time last week, Dan Cregan was a little-known first-term Liberal backbencher representing a blue-ribbon Adelaide Hills seat. Now he is Speaker. Here's how the unprecedented coup unfolded.

column1: Korean-language series Squid Game is Netflix's biggest original show debut
column2: Hit series Squid Game is Netflix's biggest ever debut of an original show, outpacing Bridgerton in just 27 days.

column1: NT government warns 'mass mortuaries' could be needed if COVID enters remote areas with low vaccination
column2: The Northern Territory's Chief Health Officer has warned shipping containers and cold storage facilities may be used as mass mortuaries in a worst-case COVID outbreak scenario.

column1: Police confirm bone found in Mossy Point garden bed is human

column1: How the AFL favours clubs who lose their stars to free agency
column2: There have been a lot of changes to the AFL in recent years, but few are bigger than the reintroduction of free agency. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson look at the impacts.

column1: Andy Murray supports restrictions on unvaccinated players at Australian Open

column1: US set to reopen land borders for fully vaccinated travellers

column1: The pressure is growing on Queensland and WA to explain what living with COVID-19 will look like

column1: Former NSW premier Mike Baird to give evidence at Berejiklian corruption inquiry
column2: The state's corruption watchdog's inquiry into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian will begin on Monday with her predecessor Mike Baird expected to give evidence on Wednesday.

column1: Call for more jail time as 'selfish' AFL grand final border breachers plead guilty
column2: The prosecution is calling for an immediate jail term for the two Victorian men after risking turning the AFL grand final into a 'super spreader event'.

column1: After childbirth, a season off and two weeks' quarantine, a Melbourne Renegades star re-emerges
column2: Cross-code star Jess Duffin takes to the cricket pitch for the WBBL opening round this weekend confident her teammates will step in as honorary nannies for her young daughter Georgie.

column1: Businesses will soon be forced to report when they are held to ransom through cyber attacks

column1: Man bitten by shark offshore in north Queensland

column1: For 10 minutes, a Times Square billboard shamed Australia on climate

column1: After unprecedented snub by Asian neighbours, Myanmar frees political prisoners

column1: 200 Queenslanders may die of COVID-19 when borders reopen, modelling predicts
column2: COVID-19 modelling suggests about 200 people in Queensland could die in the three months after borders reopen to New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT.

column1: 'Little me would be over the moon': Meet new yellow wiggle, Tsehay Hawkins
column2: Fifteen-year-old Latin dance champion, Tsehay Hawkins, takes over as Yellow Wiggle after trailblazer Emma Watkins calls time on her 11-year stint.

column1: Albury aged care cluster claims life, officials 'expect more cases'

column1: Wine exports to China down 77 per cent, but Hong Kong develops raging thirst
column2: Hong Kong's demand for Australian wine lifted by 135 per cent and South-East Asia by 43 per cent in the 12 months to September, showing Australian winemakers are diversifying away from their former key market.

column1: 'The zip was open, Cleo was gone': Mother recalls last time she saw missing four-year-old daughter

column1: Woman raped, assaulted by ex-partner in Darwin says attacks 'changed the way I live'

column1: Injured Boomers star ruled out of entire NBA season

column1: Young Aussie prospect chases Major League Baseball career after dreaming of playing in the AFL

column1: Geraldton police officer accused of murder fights back tears as he recounts day of fatal shooting
column2: WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains an image of a person who has died. A police officer accused of murdering an Indigenous woman tells a court he thought she was going to stab him when he pulled the trigger and fatally shot her.

column1: Tasmanian college apologises over skirt-length incident
column2: A Tasmanian principal has apologised after year 8 female students were asked to kneel to have their skirts measured

column1: This 4yo called police — hear what happened next

column2: New tier 1 exposure sites have been listed in Bendigo, Donald, and Traralgon.

column2: As the University of Tasmania progresses its move into the Hobart CBD, it is creating plans for its old Sandy Bay campus.

column2: A Chinese activist is dismayed LinkedIn in China will shut down later this year, after internet rules were tightened by Beijing.

column1: How the Formula 1 championship could be decided by two major unknown factors
column2: With just six points separating this year's title contenders, Lewis Hamilton and Max Verstappen will both have used engines and new circuits to deal with.

column1: We all know the health risks of smoking and drinking. But is renting a health risk?
column2: As many as a million Australians live in housing that harms their health, according to experts, and renters suffer the most.
column3: Stephen Smiley, Ange Lavoipierre, and Scott Mitchell

column1: New generation speed cameras will be able to spot more than speeding
column2: Eight new speed cameras could bust Tasmanian drivers committing other offences — but that will require a law change

column1: Many questions left unanswered after Queensland records first local COVID case in more than two weeks

column1: Does this penguin hold an Australian bank account? If not, who owns the money from Bouvet Island?
column2: If you've never heard of Bouvet Island, you're not alone. It's the most remote island on Earth and no-one lives there. But there are a dozen Australian bank accounts whose owners are registered as residents.

column1: The puppets and puppetmasters behind the Olympics 2032 and how your $5 billion will be spent
column2: A week after they were expected to be introduced, the laws governing the Brisbane 2032 organising committee remain under negotiation.

column1: Andrew Gaze to Ben Simmons: 'Get back on the floor'
column2: Australian basketball legend, Andrew Gaze, says Ben Simmons has to make up with the Philadelphia 76ers and "get back on the floor" if he is going to salvage anything out of his prodigious talent.

column1: The Spring Carnival explained: Handicaps, weights and WFA — what does it all mean?
column2: The Spring Racing Carnival is well underway, and as we get closer to the Melbourne Cup, we explain the differences between handicaps and weight-for-age races — and what a horse's weight tells us about its chances in the race that stops the nation?

column1: 'Will we survive?': Canberrans can shop again as retail stores reopen in the ACT
column2: Canberra's non-essential retail stores reopen to the public today as COVID-19 restrictions ease again — and for some businesses, it couldn't have come at a better time.

column2: Tasmanians are set to learn today how the state will emerge from border restrictions and what it will mean for the economy and the health system.

column1: Salim Hamze kept a gun close by, but his daily routine made him an easy target
column2: Sydney's latest victim of gangland violence was only 18 but was already part of multiple criminal networks when he and his father were shot in broad daylight. Their killers remain on the run, leaving residents in Western Sydney on edge.

column1: Elephants are ditching their tusks to dodge poachers — but there's a downside
column2: Ivory hunting has pressured a population of African elephants to lose their tusks, researchers say, providing striking evidence of rapid evolution driven by humans.

column1: These graphs tell the story of Sydney coming back to life after 100 days of lockdown
column2: Mobility and traffic data shows Sydneysiders are making the most of their new freedom. But, it might be a while before things go back to pre-pandemic levels.

column1: Murder downgraded to manslaughter and 57 months jail for former policeman who killed Justine Damond
column2: Mohamed Noor was initially convicted of third-degree murder and manslaughter in the 2017 fatal shooting, but had his murder conviction overturned.

column1: Congratulations Melbourne, you made it out of lockdown. Here's a reminder of what's changed
column2: Lost track of how many people you're allowed at your picnic, whether you can get a haircut or when you can start planning your wedding? Here's a reminder of what changes under this step out of COVID-19 restrictions.

column1: At least 150 dead, thousands stranded as flooding wreaks havoc in Nepal and India
column2: Days of heavy rains take their toll as landslides destroy homes and infrastructure and leave thousands of people stranded.

column1: Court told alleged stabbing, shooting in Adelaide's north-west sparked by naked photo
column2: Two men charged over an alleged attack on a Semaphore man yesterday have faced court, both applying for bail.

column1: Iconic outback hotel to get $100m makeover
column2: Iris Capital expects to spend more than $100 million on refurbishing Lasseters Hotel and Casino, which was made famous in the iconic 1994 film Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.

column1: After months in lockdown, a weary world is ready to dance
column2: Even in the depths of the pandemic including in lockdown, some are dancing in their kitchen, on the streets, on rooftops.

column1: Gut-wrenching evidence heard after death of a 'beautiful boy in a not-so-beautiful system'
column2: The father of the 20-year-old, who died in custody in NSW in 2019, has told an inquest that to anyone else his boy "may be just another number". "To me," the father said, "he was my oldest son".

column2: If you were a gay man in Sydney during the 1970s to 1990s, there was a chance you could get beaten up or killed, Garry Wotherspoon says. A memorial to the victims now stands on the eastern suburbs site where many of these acts of violence took place.

column1: World's biggest Triceratops skeleton sells for more than $10 million
column2: The enormous skeleton, estimated to be over 66 million years old and known as Big John, is sold to a private buyer from the United States.

column1: When can I come to Tasmania? How many COVID cases is the state expecting? Here's what we know
column2: Tasmania was quick to pull up the drawbridge when coronavirus started to spread throughout Australia but it now faces the prospect of hundreds of COVID-19 cases a day.

column1: Kids' clothing shops, bakeries across WA urged to help in search for Cleo Smith
column2: Police urge businesses such as children's clothing stores and bakeries within a 1,000 kilometre radius of the camp site where Cleo Smith disappeared to submit CCTV or dashcam footage.

column1: Police say Alec Baldwin fired a gun. One person is dead, another is in hospital. What happened?
column2: One of Hollywood's biggest names, Alec Baldwin, has been caught up in a tragedy on the set of his movie Rust, allegedly firing a prop gun that killed one person and injured another. Here's what we know.

column1: $330m pumped into Murray-Darling projects 'that support thriving agriculture and communities'
column2: NSW and the Commonwealth have thrown $330 million to ensure the Murray-Darling Basin Plan is met on time and "in a way that doesn't impact irrigators".

column1: Biden says United States would come to Taiwan's defence

column1: 'Better than nothing', but Bluesfest stallholders 'appalled' after long wait for partial refund

column1: Perth mum who felt 'relieved' after feeding bleach to seriously ill baby is jailed
column2: A Perth mother who told police she wanted 'a good night's sleep' when she confessed to feeding bleach to her seriously ill baby will spend at least 15 months behind bars.

column1: Tasmania to throw open borders to COVID hotspots December 15
column2: All vaccinated interstate and international arrivals can enter Tasmania without a need for quarantine from December 15, as long as they have returned a negative COVID test, the state government announces.

column1: Former NSW Labor minister Obeid ordered to go to prison tomorrow
column2: Eddie Obeid was allowed home on bail yesterday after being convicted over a mine licence conspiracy because of fears he could catch COVID-19 in prison.

column1: Students will no longer have to wear masks as SA's COVID-19 first dose vaccination rate reaches 80pc
column2: Masks will no longer be compulsory at high schools from Monday, South Australian Premier Steven Marshall announces as the state is on track to reach 80 per cent of first doses during a COVID-19 vaccination blitz this weekend.

column1: Alec Baldwin fires prop gun, killing cinematographer on set of latest film, authorities say
column2: Actor Alec Baldwin fired a prop gun on a movie set in New Mexico on Thursday, killing cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and wounding director Joel Souza, authorities say.

column1: Leaving everyone, everything she knew behind saved Ruby's life

column1: 'There is no evidence': Judge ends perjury trial of Queensland police superintendent
column2: A senior Gold Coast police officer is acquitted of perjury after a judge instructed a jury to find her not guilty for giving false testimony to the Crime and Corruption Commission.

column1: Evergrande reportedly pays bondholders $110 million, averting default for now
column2: Reports reveal Evergrande remitted $US83 million ($110 million) to a trustee account at Citibank on Thursday, allowing it to pay bondholders overdue interest before a grace period expires tomorrow.

column1: Why did the Queen go to hospital? Here's what we know about the monarch's health

column1: Western Bulldogs premiership captain Easton Wood retires after 14-year AFL career
column2: After 188 games and a famous premiership, Western Bulldogs defender Easton Wood is calling time on his 14-year AFL career.

column1: Australia and the world right to be worried about democracy after Trump: Bob Woodward

column1: Here's where Qantas and Jetstar are flying to as international travel opens up
column2: Flights to the international destinations will only be available to passengers who are fully vaccinated and return a negative COVID test.

column1: What happens when you're stuck in China but all your stuff is still in Australia?
column2: The travel bans that trapped thousands of international students, who had been studying at Australian universities, in China also created an unexpected business opportunity.

column1: Inside an Instagram influencer's daring escape from Malaysia to Australia

column1: How the words 'sweetheart deal' raised eyebrows at the ICAC inquiry into Gladys Berejiklian
column2: As he penned a jest-filled memo quoting a Tom Cruise character to the NSW premier in 2016, a political strategist could never have known it would become evidence at a corruption inquiry.

column1: Wisdom is helping these older Victorians weather pandemic

column2: The 63-year-old 30 Rock and Saturday Night Live actor was seen distraught outside the sheriff's office after what his spokesperson called a misfire of a prop gun.

column1: 'Rules of the jungle': China ups the rhetoric against Australia, US and UK over AUKUS deal

column1: Robert Durst, subject of documentary of The Jinx, charged over 1982 murder of wife

column1: K-Pop superstars BTS deal Sony music a fresh blow

column1: Alleged nightclub dancing breach referred to Cricket Australia

column2: The ACT records 24 new locally acquired cases of COVID-19, as Canberrans begin their first weekend since both essential and non-essential retail outlets were permitted to reopen.

column1: Rudy Giuliani ally Lev Parnas guilty of violating US campaign finance laws

column1: Anthony Fields confident new Yellow Wiggle can fill big shoes left by Emma Watkins

column1: Female surfers' fight for equal pay part of ongoing battle for recognition, respect

column1: Conservationists are buying back blocks in the Daintree, but not all the locals are happy

column1: Seoul's secretive tattoo industry inks up Brad Pitt and BTS. But they are in constant fear of arrest

column1: Budget is not the only strain on first home buyers. The emotional toll is harder to calculate

column1: North Korea remains on war footing — and Joe Biden is right to be wary

column1: Olympic sprinter Alex Quiñónez killed in Ecuador along with another man

column1: Roadside bombing targeting the Taliban kills two, including a child, in Afghanistan

column1: Russian, Chinese warships hold first joint patrols in Pacific Ocean
column2: Russia's defence ministry releases a statement saying that exercises between Moscow and Beijing were conducted between October 17 and 23 in another sign of closer ties between the two nations.

column1: Aussies scrape home to beat South Africa in tense T20 World Cup opener
