column1: Macarthur FC rocked as former Socceroo announces retirement
column2: The Bulls are looking for a new captain ahead of the A-League Men season, after goalkeeper Adam Federici calls time on his decorated career.

column1: Impressive Matildas take down Brazil in opening friendly
column2: The Matildas — playing their first match in Australia since early 2020 — outclass Brazil with a 3-1 victory in wet conditions in Sydney.

column1: Asylum seekers detained in Melbourne hotel test positive to COVID-19
column2: At least 17 asylum seekers detained in a Melbourne facility test positive to COVID-19, with one person being treated in hospital.

column1: Thousands of teachers could be absent from schools on Monday
column2: When the state government changed the date of when schools could reopen across Greater Sydney, it left thousands of teachers unable to get fully vaccinated and allowed to return to classrooms next week, the NSW Teachers Federation president says.

column1: Rollout of COVID-19 vaccine booster shots likely to follow a familiar timeline
column2: Australia's medical regulator will look at new data from Pfizer on COVID-19 booster doses on Monday, with health authorities hopeful of a November rollout.

column1: Forensics officers gathering evidence of possible scoping at Cleo Smith's home
column2: A week after four-year-old Cleo Smith disappeared, a forensics squad is gathering evidence at the family's Carnarvon home. The ABC understands police are investigating someone had scoped the house, but there is no suggestion that Cleo's family were involved in her disappearance.

column1: Wallabies earn gritty Test win over plucky Japan
column2: The Wallabies are made to earn their 32-23 victory over Japan in Oita, as their spring tour kicks off in triumphant fashion.

column1: COVID twist in search for man still missing in outback Queensland
column2: A camper who was with the missing man has tested positive to the virus and five Queensland police are isolating or in quarantine, complicating the search for a man last seen almost a week ago.

column1: Wound 'infested with maggots', harassment and choking death at Darwin aged care home detailed in new report
column2: Instances of suffering, harassment and staffing shortages at Darwin's NT Regis Tiwi aged care home are detailed in a new report. Prior to the report's release, the NT government said it would send additional elderly patients there to free up beds at the Royal Darwin Hospital.

column1: Picasso artworks fetch more than $134 million at Las Vegas auction
column2: Eleven Picasso artworks that helped turn Las Vegas into an unlikely destination for art have been sold at an auction for more than $134 million.

column1: WA Police reveal search for passenger vehicle seen in Blowholes area where Cleo Smith disappeared
column2: WA police reveal they are searching for a passenger vehicle seen in the Blowholes area when four-year-old Cleo Smith disappeared just over a week ago.

column1: Atlanta Braves reach first World Series in 22 years
column2: The Braves advance to a World Series match-up against the Houston Astros after beating the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League Championship.

column1: Nationals provide in-principle support for net zero 2050 target
column2: Barnaby Joyce confirms the majority of Nationals members have given in-principle support to back a target of net zero emissions by 2050, ending a years-long standoff within the Coalition on climate change policy.

column1: Year 12 exam result 'integrity' in doubt, SA union claims
column2: Days after the start of school exams in South Australia, doubts have been raised about the reliability of Year 12 results amid upheaval within the state's education assessment agency — but the SACE Board hit back, saying the claims are nothing more than "scaremongering".

column1: Coffs Harbour battered again as hail slams parts of regional NSW
column2: The SES is busy today responding to up to 500 calls for assistance after hail left a "massive mess" in parts of the state.

column1: All of Victoria will be on the same COVID restrictions from Friday. Here's what that means for you
column2: Victoria will reach its 80 per cent double dose vaccination milestone almost a week ahead of schedule, granting residents more freedoms, the government announces.

column1: Italian right-wing leader ridicules calling of actor Richard Gere in migrant ship trial
column2: The leader of Italy's right-wing League Party says a trial in which he is facing kidnapping charges for refusing to let a migrant ship dock in the country is not to be taken seriously after US actor Richard Gere is admitted to testify.

column1: Darcie Brown hat-trick not enough for Strikers against Heat in WBBL
column2: Not even a rare WBBL hat-trick from Darcie Brown can see the Adelaide Strikers over the line against the Brisbane Heat, who move to the top of the table.

column1: Colombia's most wanted drug lord captured in jungle raid
column2: Colombia's president says the capture of Dairo Antonio Úsuga is "the biggest blow against drug trafficking in our country this century".

column1: 'Mackenzie's gift': IVF testing for genetic disorders added to Medicare
column2: From next month, Australians going through IVF will be able to claim a Medicare rebate for pre-implantation genetic testing to help prevent passing serious genetic disorders onto their child.

column1: NSW launches campaign to lure tourists back with less focus on iconic landmarks
column2: As NSW prepares to open to the rest of the world next month, a multi-million-dollar tourism campaign is launched that focuses less on the iconic landmarks and more on natural experiences.

column1: Man charged over fatal moped crash that killed two men
column2: A Queensland man is charged with callous disregard of an injured person as part of an investigation into a fatal moped traffic crash in Brisbane that killed two men.

column1: Experts say it's time Victoria started talking about using recycled water for drinking

column1: Australian discus great Dani Stevens calls time on decorated career
column2: Twelve years after becoming the youngest-ever discus world champion, Dani Stevens brings her long and decorated athletics career to an end.

column1: 'Stabilise the country': Collapse imminent for Taliban-led Afghanistan, warn observing nations
column2: Afghanistan is likely to collapse "faster than we thought" without the support of the international community, Sweden and Pakistan leaders say.

column1: 'Locked Down Trivia' helps lift spirits while raising funds

column1: Teens arrested over Uber driver assault, pedestrian injured by burnout
column2: During a busy night on the roads for SA Police, five teens were charged with aggravated assault, a woman was hospitalised after being hit by a car doing a burnout, and a man was allegedly detected speeding while more than three times the legal alcohol limit.

column1: Queensland records zero COVID-19 cases as pop-up vaccine clinics set to open at theme parks, surf clubs
column2: As Queensland hits a new vaccine milestone, authorities announce pop-up vaccine clinics will open at major theme parks and surf life saving clubs over the upcoming long weekend.

column1: ACT records nine new cases of COVID-19 as the territory leads the way on vaccinations

column1: Advantage Red Bull as Verstappen takes pole in US Grand Prix

column1: The 10,000m rule, the 'hit-and-run' or something in between — what does a horse's Melbourne Cup prep look like?
column2: On the eve of the Melbourne Cup, we look at how past winners have prepared for the big race, and how the approach trainers take for the lead-up to Flemington has changed.

column1: 18yo jockey in induced coma after Kalgoorlie racecourse fall
column2: Apprentice jockey Hannah Fitzgerald remains in a critical condition at Royal Perth Hospital after a tragic incident at Kalgoorlie racecourse on Saturday.

column1: What will life be like for South Australia once borders are open?
column2: Modelling by the University of Adelaide looking at the number of hospitalisations and deaths from COVID is released to South Australians, but what does it all mean?

column1: Japan's newly minted PM defies expectation in big election victory
column2: Despite taking some notable hits, Japan's newly elected Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and his long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party defied expectations to retain a majority.

column1: Cattle and real estate markets are bullish. So would you buy a house or a cow?
column2: While house prices have climbed, beef prices have exploded. Loxton stud breeder Alizah Fogden and her partner decided to use some of the money they had saved for a house deposit to buy more cows.

column1: Daughter of woman missing for 43 years just wants 'continual nightmare' to end
column2: Kathryn Gray was eight years old when she last saw her mum and, while the memories have begun to fade, the pain of not knowing what happened to her remains.

column1: Texas anti-abortion bounty hunter law a work of 'sinister genius' proving hard to challenge
column2: The US Supreme Court is facing hearings on abortion laws that promise to set the parameters for the most dramatic month for reproductive rights in three decades.

column1: ANU college denies it failed in its duty of care over former student's sexual assault
column2: The Australian National University's John XXIII College is appealing the ACT Supreme Court's finding that it failed in its duty of care after a former student was sexually assaulted.

column1: 'Organoids' could take the guesswork out of finding the most-effective neurological drugs
column2: About a third of people with epilepsy never achieve effective seizure control, but University of Queensland researchers hope they can soon end the trial and error of treatment and better predict the drug combinations for individual patients.

column1: From last in Toowoomba to Melbourne Cup favourite. This is the rise of Incentivise
column2: The five-year-old goes into the Cup on the back of nine straight wins, a streak that began with his maiden victory in April. But his career hasn't always been glorious wins and big pay cheques.

column1: Families will be forced to isolate for 14 days at home if just one member gets COVID-19 in Queensland
column2: Queensland Health Minister Yvette D'Ath says "opening up" will only work if the state continued to test, trace, isolate and quarantine.

column1: Queensland's unvaxxed workers could be a legal timebomb, lawyer warns
column2: One of Australia's top employment lawyers says Queensland businesses could be at risk of costly legal headaches if their unvaccinated workers spread COVID-19.

column1: 'It's unfair': The millionaires who want to pay more tax
column2: House prices and the share market have ballooned, but wages are barely growing — a combination widening the gap between those who make money from assets and those who make it from labour.

column1: From neglected child to takeover target, what a mega deal says about aquaculture
column2: Moves by a global meat processing giant to take over a local salmon-farming champion suggests Australia's fledgling aquaculture industry is finally growing up.

column1: Tasmania has been racing to the 80pc fully vaccinated target. Will it cross the finish line today?
column2: In September, Tasmanian Premier Peter Gutwein declared the state was in a race to reach 80 per cent fully vaccinated against COVID by Melbourne Cup day. Is the state likely to reach that milestone today?

column1: Sophia loved the high she got from buy now, pay later services — until she couldn't make repayments
column2: Popular buy now, pay later services — two of the biggest players being Afterpay and Zip — are continuing to grow in popularity. However, if you're toying with the idea of opening an account, or multiple accounts, read on to find out the risks first.

column1: Online subscription services for the pill providing convenient alternative, but doctors warn of risks
column2: For some women, seeing a doctor to renew their script for the contraceptive pill can be costly, inconvenient and in some instances, just straight out stressful, but new online subscription services are providing an alternative.

column1: 'I can literally never forget': Prachi and Hai lost their loved ones to COVID but their fight isn't over
column2: The ABC spoke to five people from around the world about the toll COVID-19 has taken, both on their communities and on them personally.
column3: Erin Handley, Som Patidar, Sastra Wijaya, Catherine Graue, and Bang Xiao

column1: Sunshine forecast, roses in bloom as crowds return to Flemington for the 2021 Melbourne Cup
column2: For the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic began, thousands of Melbourne Cup fans will descend on Flemington today to watch in person the race that stops a nation.

column1: She lived to 104 but Moi-Yo Miller's adventures included performing magic in Berlin when World War II began
column2: The world of stage magic in Australia was a male affair, until Esme Levante, Myrtle Roberts and Moi-Yo Miller came along.

column1: Boris Johnson tells Glasgow climate summit world is facing 'doomsday'
column2: The planet will face "doomsday" if world leaders do not pull off a "James Bond" victory, UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson says at the official opening ceremony of the climate summit in Glasgow.

column1: 'I have no regrets': Hong Kong activists go on trial over banned Tiananmen Square vigil
column2: Media tycoon Jimmy Lai and the seven others face charges over their roles in an unauthorised vigil marking the Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing.

column1: 'I'm not going to cop sledging': Morrison rejects French criticism over submarine deal
column2: Scott Morrison takes aim at what he describes as the French government's "sledging" of Australia, rejecting President Emmanuel Macron's assertion he lied to him about the $90 billion submarine contract.

column1: Biden tests negative for COVID following press secretary's positive result
column2: US President Joe Biden returns a negative COVID test after being tested on his way to the COP26 climate talks in Glasgow.

column1: Indigenous justice advocate named NT Australian of the Year in moving ceremony
column2: The woman described as the "driving force" behind an agreement aimed at reducing Indigenous incarceration rates and improving justice outcomes in the Northern Territory has been named the 2022 NT Australian of the Year.

column1: British bank boss steps down over report into Epstein links
column2: Barclays chief executive Jes Staley steps down following a report by UK regulators into his ties with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

column1: Perth mother jailed after eight-year-old almost died from sexually transmitted infection given to her by stepfather
column2: A Perth mother will spend at least three years behind bars after failing to protect her eight-year-old daughter, who almost died from a sexually transmitted infection after being molested by her stepfather.

column1: 44yo accused of murdering lifelong best friend with samurai sword faces trial
column2: The court heard Damian Beckerleg and James Reimers had been close mates since they were five, but an afternoon of fishing and drinking earlier this year ended with what the defence called an "extraordinary and tragic" death.

column1: 5 million people have officially died from COVID-19. But who's not being counted?
column2: Five million people — or the equivalent of New Zealand's entire population — have succumbed to COVID-19 worldwide. But that's only the official tally, with the real death toll likely to be as much as four times higher, writes Casey Briggs.

column1: Unexplained gas funding timeline a 'very dark day for the Commonwealth', Federal Court judge says
column2: Lawyers for environmental advocates question whether the federal government fast-tracked an agreement to provide funding to a gas company in a bid to hinder legal action challenging the grant.

column1: Attorney-General owns land 'across the road' from forest impacted by port decision, committee hears
column2: A former managing director of the company behind a proposed port on Kangaroo Island tells a parliamentary inquiry Attorney-General Vickie Chapman should have excused herself from the decision-making process.

column1: Elon Musk says he'll donate billions to fight world hunger, but only if a UN agency meets his conditions
column2: Elon Musk, the world's richest person, says he will donate $US6 billion to the UN's initiative to address world hunger if the global body can meet his terms around transparency and accounting.

column1: Former NT police officer found not guilty of aggravated assault
column2: The Alice Springs Local Court heard Chris Tencate was using his taser to create a light show for his infant son during his lunch break and he denied using the weapon to scare his wife.

column1: Man charged with attempted murder over violent fight in Darwin suburb
column2: Police charge three men — one of them with attempted murder — after a Karama fight that allegedly involved a number of people armed with poles and edged weapons.

column1: PM makes each-way bet on climate change at COP26
column2: While Australians put their money on horses today, Scott Morrison had a wager of his own: An each-way bet that $20 billion in technological investments will either fix the climate crisis, or at least convince other nations Australia is doing enough.

column1: Man shocked at process to get through WA hard border as he arrives in Perth to see sick mother
column2: A man who made it through WA's hard border to see his sick mother commends the WA Government for wanting to keep people safe, but says he's shocked at the process he had to go through to make it home to Perth.

column1: 'Shocked and saddened': Alec Baldwin's assistant director calls for reform
column2: Rust assistant director David Halls releases a statement to the New York Post,  saying he is shocked and saddened by the October 21 death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins in New Mexico and the industry must "reevaluate its values and practices".

column1: World leaders agree to stop deforestation by 2030
column2: More than 100 leaders representing more than 85 per cent of the world's forests agree to end logging but environmental activists are calling for swifter action.

column1: Vax named 2021's word of the year by Oxford dictionary
column2: The explanation for this word's vast expansion is simply viral. No word better captures the atmosphere of the past year than vax.

column1: 'Some of the biggest waste in the nation's history': Questions over $38b in JobKeeper handouts
column2: Analysis by the federal Parliamentary Budget Office found that $38 billion in JobKeeper payments went to employers that did not suffer sustained downturns below threshold levels.

column1: Foster carer details financial troubles in 13yo SA boy's suicide coronial inquest
column2: The former foster carer of a 13-year-old boy who took his own life while in state care tells a coronial inquest that he was unable to care for him because he could not make ends meet.

column1: France's President is calling Scott Morrison a liar. How did we get here?
column2: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has been called a liar by French President Emmanuel Macron while on the international stage. But did Mr Morrison mislead the French over his intentions on the submarine deal, or was the arrangement already dead in the water?

column1: Women's and Children's Hospital reveals number of unvaccinated staff, protesters gather in Adelaide CBD
column2: The CEO of Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital reveals 133 staff have refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19 and have been forced to take leave. Meanwhile, dozens of anti-mandatory vaccination protesters rally in the CBD.

column1: What caused Hobart's spooky Halloween sunset?
column2: Trick or treaters across Hobart on Sunday saw an eerie sight in the evening sky that mirrored the spooky streets below. But the answer to what caused the strange clouds is fairly straightforward.

column1: Australia's most decorated Olympian Emma McKeon's message to world leaders gathering in Glasgow
column2: Five-time Olympic gold medallist Emma McKeon joins Olympic and Paralympic champions with a message for world leaders gathering at the COP26 Summit in Glasgow.

column1: Where every horse finished in the Melbourne Cup
column2: The Melbourne Cup has been run and won at Flemington - here's where every one of the 23 horses finished.

column1: Researcher refuses vaccines because he's had a dose of his own COVID-19 jab
column2: An Adelaide medical researcher who has developed and been administered with his own COVID-19 vaccine says he is facing the sack because of his refusal to get one of the TGA-approved jabs.

column1: Man who allegedly set ex-partner on fire likely used accelerant, court told
column2: Medical experts have given evidence in the attempted murder trial of a man who allegedly set his partner alight, saying the pattern of her burns indicates an accelerant was used.

column1: Verry Elleegant secures the biggest win of her career, winning the Melbourne Cup
column2: Despite never winning beyond 2,400m going into the race, Verry Elleegant has secured the biggest win of her career with Melbourne Cup glory at Flemington.

column1: Ho ho ho turns to no no no as Queensland restrictions slay Santa bookings

column1: Councillor calls for review of children's books about racism, gender identity

column1: Why the most important part of Berejiklian ICAC hearings is actually a little boring
column2: The ICAC hearings into Gladys Berejiklian's conduct weren't as explosive as previous probes, but they shone an important light on process, writes state political reporter Ashleigh Raper.

column1: Cleo snatched in ‘opportunistic attack’, police believe, as phone footage places her at camp on night in question

column1: Reserve Bank may be pressured to lift interest rates as early as 2022

column1: Australian dollar tumbles after RBA decision, ASX to follow Wall Street higher
column2: The Australian dollar fell to 74.3 US cents as the market regarded the Reserve Bank's decision as "dovish", while Wall Street is on track to end its day at record highs.

column1: Live: NSW Now: Doctor's association backs delayed freedoms for unvaccinated
column2: MORNING BRIEFING: The AMA says the NSW government's decision to delay freedoms for unvaccinated residents might be the push some people need to get their first jab.

column1: 'Our most vulnerable group of people': COVID-19 vaccination mandate needed for aged care visitors, peak body says
column2: The peak body for aged care centres wants a mandate brought in for visitors to be vaccinated against COVID-19 but experts are divided.

column1: Here we go again: Another wet, stormy trough on the way
column2: A trough extending from the Great Australian Bight all the way to the tropics is set to bring another soggy few days and the chance of storms as it sweeps across the country.

column1: Australia refuses to join global pledge to cut methane emissions
column2: Australia snubs one of the key global actions to come out of the UN climate change conference by bowing out of an international pledge to reduce methane emissions.

column1: 'Not unusual it never gets seen again': Boat missing in Tasmania may not be found, says expert
column2: The body of missing Tasmanian man Thomas Courto and the boat he was travelling in are still missing. So how does a boat just vanish in Bass Strait without a trace?

column1: Foreign Minister to visit South-East Asia to ease fears over nuclear submarine plan

column1: Who's hot, who's not at WBBL halfway mark?
column2: It's the halfway mark in the WBBL regular season, so who's hot, who's not and who's just starting to warm up? Which teams are likely to make a move in the second half of the competition?

column1: 'Clean up our own backyard': Australian miners ramp up plans to cut carbon emissions
column2: Fossil fuels are fast losing favour in Australia as some of the country's biggest miners shift to a greener business model.

column1: The Australian bushfire survivor taking on Scott Morrison at the Glasgow climate summit
column2: Jo Dodds knows what it is like to be on the climate change frontline, so she went to COP26 to pressure governments into doing more about the crisis.

column1: Vaccines for children are coming. These are the frontrunners

column1: Frydenberg warned less than three months into JobKeeper that millions were going to firms with rising turnovers
column2: The ABC confirms the federal Treasurer was alerted less than three months into JobKeeper that businesses were getting taxpayer support for six months while increasing their turnovers.

column1: Australia looks like a climate laggard, as other countries ramp-up efforts
column2: The government is confident Australia will cut emissions by more than 26 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030, but data shows our ambition is insufficient by almost any measure.

column1: 'He needs help, not kicked when he's down': Mum's fight for son's mental health

column1: 'You're going to feel seen': New movie puts Western Sydney on the map
column2: A new film which intertwines the stories of eight Western Sydney writers seeks to capture the richness of life in a sometimes forgotten and misunderstood part of Australia.

column1: 'Leave it a better place': How tourism can help combat climate change
column2: Tourism operators might be hoping for a return to normal but a sustainable tourism expert says there is an even better option.
column3: Simon Leo Brown and Victoria Pengilley

column1: The EU is about to put Australia back on the emissions hook with a carbon tariff
column2: A carbon tariff is a carbon tax applied to exports from countries like Australia that don't have one. And Europe is planning to impose one, whether our politicians like it or not, writes Peter Martin.
column3: Simon Leo Brown and Victoria Pengilley

column1: 'Made in China' might be cheap, but it comes with a human cost
column2: Heavy consumption in the world's largest economies could be responsible for nearly 2 million premature deaths globally from air pollution every year, according to new modelling.

column1: At least 25 killed as blasts, gunfire hit Kabul hospital
column2: The explosions happened at the entrance of the 400-bed Sardar Mohammad Daud Khan hospital, according to a Taliban spokesperson, who says four of the attackers were killed by security forces.

column1: New figures reveal almost 400 healthcare workers across SA are refusing to be vaccinated against COVID-19
column2: Almost 400 South Australian health sector workers have been forced to take leave after refusing to be vaccinated against COVID-19, according to figures released by SA Health.

column1: Beds and medical services cut as Queensland hospital workers defy COVID-19 vaccination mandate
column2: Of the state's 108,000 Hospital and Health Services workers, 3,830 — or 3.54 per cent — have provided no evidence of a COVID-19 vaccination and are not on leave, forcing cuts to surgical, medical and mental health beds, Queensland Health data obtained by the ABC shows.

column1: Search underway after fisherman falls out of tinnie into Queensland dam
column2: Specialist divers have been dispatched to help look for the man, who fell out of his boat earlier today.

column1: How will Macron's 'liar' claim play out with Morrison's voters?
column2: Scott Morrison's spat with the French President is bad for his international reputation. But on the home front, the PM will reckon on neutralising Emmanuel Macron's allegation,  writes Michelle Grattan.

column1: Meet the high-ranking Indigenous soldier blazing a trail in the military
column2: Lieutenant Colonel Eileen Hall, who's been honoured at a ceremony attended by the top brass at her home country in far north Queensland, wants to inspire not only First Nations people but all women to consider a military career.

column1: Cleo Smith case 'breaks all the rules' of child abduction, criminologist says

column1: 'Everyone just had tears of joy': Carnarvon locals celebrate Cleo Smith's return
column2: Celebrations are in full swing in Carnarvon as locals breathe a collective sigh of relief over the safe return of Cleo Smith, who was found alive this morning after vanishing from the Blowholes campgrounds more than two weeks ago.

column1: Expat races to see dying mum after receiving 11th-hour quarantine exemption
column2: Paul Stewart's journey from London to reunite with his dying mother has not been an easy one due to the NT's strict border rules.

column1: 'We're going to take you to see your mummy and daddy': Heartwarming video of moment Cleo is rescued released by police

column1: Las Vegas Raiders release NFL player after fatal car crash
column2: Henry Ruggs III — a rising star in the NFL — is let go by the Raiders following his involvement in a fatal motor vehicle accident in Las Vegas.

column1: Attorney-General denies conflict of interest around Kangaroo Island house near plantation
column2: South Australian Attorney-General Vickie Chapman tells a parliamentary committee she received rental income from a property that would have been affected by a major port development which she subsequently blocked.

column1: South Australian mother who tried to kill autistic son released into community
column2: A South Australian single mother who was "having great difficulty in coping" when she tried to kill herself and her son is released into the community on licence.

column1: Probe finds 'poor leadership', lack of enthusiasm for safety at Caboolture hospital
column2: Empathy training is recommended for all staff at Caboolture Hospital after a probe finds there was poor leadership and a lack of enthusiasm for safety and quality.

column1: Videos of high school student brawl sparks investigation
column2: Tasmania Police are investigating after footage emerged of a fight involving a large number of students at a Hobart high school, with a cyber-bullying expert warning the videos being circulated will only add to the harm.

column1: Scott Morrison may want to 'move on', but leaking Macron’s private texts only ensures French fury will linger
column2: The Prime Minister may have felt justifiably injured after being branded a liar on the world stage, but this was the time for a cool head, not a hot one, writes Andrew Probyn.

column1: Police release hospital photo of Cleo Smith as officer recounts 'best moment of his career'
column2: Police post a photo of a smiling Cleo Smith in hospital as the officer who found her in a house in Carnarvon recounts the incredible story of her rescue.

column1: Darwin shooter apologises in court, explains why he pleaded guilty
column2: Benjamin Glenn Hoffmann, who has pleaded guilty to murder and manslaughter, says there are two key reasons why he changed his plea from not guilty to guilty mid-trial.

column1: Changes to Queensland's border rules flagged as $1m stimulus comes into play
column2: Motorists may be waved through Queensland's southern border when the state opens up next month. Meanwhile, struggling business owners are cheering a timely new round of discount vouchers.
column3: Heidi Sheehan, Tara Cassidy, and Alexandria Utting

column1: House where Cleo Smith was found unremarkable, but today it's the nation's focus
column2: The house where missing four-year-old Cleo Smith was found is unremarkable in every way, yet today it is the centre of one of the biggest police investigations in West Australian history.

column1: 'Move on, frankly': PM says he has no intention of apologising to French President over sub decision
column2: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says he will not apologise to France after President Emmanuel Macron accused the PM of lies and deceit over a cancelled submarine deal.

column1: Penrith Panthers sack NRL premiership winner Tyrone May
column2: The NRL premiers cut ties with May, saying his conduct on social media after the club's grand-final victory "constituted a serious breach of his contractual obligations".

column1: Man who used cattle prod to inflict 'sadistic' violence against partner jailed
column2: A man who assaulted his former partner with a cattle prod, threatened her with a gun and forced her to sleep outside has been found guilty of 12 counts of rape and three counts of aggravated assault.

column1: Aussie batting star Pucovski 'unlikely' to play first Ashes Test
column2: Will Pucovski is ruled out of Victoria's next Sheffield Shield match as he continues his recovery from concussion, putting the Test batter in doubt for the men's Ashes opener next month at the Gabba.

column1: Atlanta Braves win World Series to snap 26-year drought
column2: For the first time since 1995, the Atlanta Braves are crowned World Series champions, after thrashing the Houston Astros in game six in Houston.

column1: WA's COVID roadmap to be released on Friday, on the eve of NSW border rules easing
column2: The WA government will release a roadmap on Friday for transitioning to living with COVID-19, a day before it downgrades New South Wales from an "extreme risk" state to "high risk".

column1: Former minister spent more than $18k in one year paying for Labor memberships, IBAC hears
column2: An electorate officer of former Victorian Labor minister Marlene Kairouz tells a corruption hearing the member for Kororoit would spend thousands of dollars a year on branch stacking by paying for other people's party memberships.

column1: Federal Court slams criminal case against ANZ as a 'complete shemozzle'
column2: Prosecutors ditch a long-running criminal case against ANZ and one of its senior executives after the Federal Court describes the matter as a "complete shemozzle" and "fairly pointless".

column1: 'Abysmal job of running health': Outback doctor has had enough
column2: A doctor on the Eyre Peninsula says he can no longer tolerate working in a system which he says has little respect for frontline medical and nursing staff.

column1: Resources Minister not required to consider climate change when awarding gas grant, lawyers argue
column2: Lawyers for the federal government are arguing the Resources Minister was not required to consider the risks of climate change when determining whether to award $21 million in grants to a gas company.

column1: The journey to Cleo Smith being found
column2: Police spent 18 days trying to find little Cleo Smith after she disappeared from the remote Blowholes campsite. Here's how the search unfolded.

column1: Today's forecast: Cloudy with a strong chance of confusion
column2: Have you ever changed social plans due to a prediction of rain that never came? It might be that you misinterpreted the forecast. So, as outdoor socialising returns, we ask the Bureau of Meteorology, how can we tell if it's really going to rain?

column1: Eight million Australian homes aren't energy efficient. Many occupants are battling change
column2: Eight million Australian homes contribute to 18 per cent of Australia's carbon emissions, a new report shows. Enacting any major change is especially hard for renters and people in low-income households.

column1: Maria James's family calls for a priest's exhumation, if DNA testing doesn't offer answers
column2: At a fresh coronial inquest into the death of a Victorian woman, the coroner warns the family of Maria James they may not get the answers they hope for, however, the answers may be found in a laboratory.

column1: Australia has a submarine-shaped hole in its defences, and few options to fill it
column2: The navy faces a looming headache on how to replace its ageing submarine fleet, one that a hurt French ambassador warns could create a 20-year hole in Australia's defences.

column1: An important detail Morrison omits when he says Australia barely contributes to global warming
column2: China's President was a no show at the Glasgow climate summit. It didn't go unnoticed by world leaders, but pointing the blame at China conveniently leaves out an important detail when it comes to global emissions.

column1: Australia was planning to phase out caged eggs by 2036, but one state is threatening to derail that
column2: Australia's long-awaited plan to phase out battery hens may be in doubt because of a so-called "captain's call" by a state minister, documents obtained under FOI laws reveal.

column1: Carnarvon residents describe man taken into police custody over Cleo Smith disapperance
column2: Local residents give details about the man living in the house where Western Australia Police found Cleo Smith.

column1: How can one side of an island get far more rain than the other?
column2: Meteorologists tend to refer to stream weather quite frequently in Tasmania — but what is it? And how does it makes the west wet, and the east dry?

column1: Launceston's GroWaverley food charity shutting down, unable to keep up with demand
column2: A popular community run food co-op has been providing much needed relief to those unable to afford fresh food, filling a gap in vital community services. However, the volunteers running the co-op can no longer keep it running.

column1: Everything you need to know about ICUs and the battle to keep COVID-19 patients alive
column2: It's the part of the hospital where health professionals provide specialised and critical care to those who need it most. If you're a COVID-19 patient, it's the last place you want to end up.

column1: Hope burns a little brighter as Diwali arrives for pandemic-weary Australian family
column2: The COVID-19 travel ban separated Parteek Mittal and Kanu Aggarwal from their youngest child. Now that Diwali has arrived, it's time to put the darkness behind.

column1: 'It's the best news the town could have asked for': Despair turns to joy for Carnarvon
column2: Searchers head to the local to pub to celebrate after four-year-old Cleo Smith found alive and well.

column1: What a palliative care doctor has learnt about delivering bad news
column2: After having a painful experience as a junior doctor, Kathryn Mannix learnt how to handle important or 'tender' conversations more successfully.

column1: As Australia's border restrictions lift, I'm nervous about returning home. Here's why
column2: Australia may be starting to reopen its borders, but after months of yearning to come home, I find myself nervous about the prospect of returning. I wonder how I can sit at Christmas or Easter lunch knowing the person passing the salt thought it was reasonable to leave me in the wilderness during an international crisis, writes Rebekah Ison.

column1: It turns out whales eat a lot more than we thought — but that's a good thing
column2: Whales consume three times more food than previously thought, and their role in ocean ecosystems and the impact of whaling may have been vastly underestimated.

column1: It's hard to remember a PM's trip running off the rails so spectacularly
column2: The Prime Minister was yesterday imploring everyone to "move on" from Australia's diplomatic row with France over the submarine deal. Perhaps they soon will. But it's difficult to see much prospect of repair in the relationship while Morrison and Macron are both in power, writes David Speers.

column1: Meet the detective who found Cleo Smith
column2: Cameron Blaine has worked on some of WA's most high-profile murders, and his appearance in a heartwarming police video of the moments after Cleo Smith was found has endeared him to many.

column1: How police discovered the 'needle in the haystack' that led them to Cleo Smith
column2: Meticulous police work — rather than an accidental sighting or pure chance — led officers to a home in Carnarvon where they discovered missing WA girl Cleo Smith.

column1: Scandinavian nations to confront past crimes against Indigenous people
column2: The governments of Sweden and Finland are setting up truth commissions to examine the countries' past treatment of and abuses against the region's Sami minority.

column1: Israeli court halts auction of Auschwitz tattoo kit
column2: An Israeli court suspends the auction of a partial tattoo kit billed as having been used on inmates at the Auschwitz death camp, following an outcry from Holocaust survivors.

column1: Thai police chief 'Joe Ferrari' charged with murder over suspect's death
column2: A Thai police colonel known for his extravagant collection of luxury cars and famous girlfriend is charged with killing a suspected drug dealer while trying to extort him for money.

column1: 'Read this': Alec Baldwin hits back at claims of 'chaos' on Rust set
column2: Actor Alec Baldwin shares a message on social media disputing reports of chaos and a lax attitude toward safety on the set of Western movie Rust, where he accidentally shot and killed a cinematographer.

column1: Mooney scores breathtaking century in Scorchers' WBBL win over Renegades
column2: Opener Beth Mooney smashes an unbeaten 101 off just 63 deliveries, as the Perth Scorchers record a comfortable 40-run win over the Melbourne Renegades.

column1: China officials attempt to soothe fears after issuing notice urging families to stockpile necessities
column2: Chinese officials back-pedal after warning families to stockpile food in case of emergencies, after panic spread on social media.

column1: Families 'floored' as pair of Secret Santas pay off 82 Christmas lay-bys at toyshop
column2: The couple, who wish to remain anonymous, told the manager of the store that they had vowed to perform such an act of kindness after struggling to pay the bills during their younger years.

column1: What this jockey overcame to ride in the Cup has 'amazed' his supporters
column2: Harry Coffey says he's never had so much support for finishing third last in a horse race. The jockey, who rode in this week's Melbourne Cup, hopes his ride inspires others with cystic fibrosis to chase their dreams.

column1: Department of Justice fined over attacks on staff, including infamous guitar 'scalping'
column2: The Department of Justice and Community Safety has  been convicted and fined $100,000, for failing to provide a safe workplace at its youth justice facilities

column1: Oliver wins record-equalling seventh Oaks after guiding Willowy to thrilling victory
column2: Veteran jockey Damien Oliver triumphs once again in the VRC Oaks, as the James Cummings-trained Willowy pips Douceur in a pulsating finish at Flemington.

column1: Women who planned genital mutilation of newborn baby saw procedure as a 'gift to God', Perth court is told
column2: A mother and grandmother avoid jail after a Perth court is told they planned the genital mutilation of a two-week-old baby because, in their culture, the procedure was seen as 'a gift to God'.

column1: Fisherman charged with stealing shark detection tag from great white
column2: A West Australian man accused of stealing a detection tag from a white pointer he caught off the state's south coast has denied the charge.

column2: Some parents at Cleo Smith's school had to figure out how to tell their kids about Cleo Smith's disappearance and rescue, while others had the good news broken to them by their children.

column2: Victorian Opposition Leader Matthew Guy is standing by his public demand that embattled Kew MP Tim Smith not contest next year's state election.

column2: A Pentagon report indicates China is expanding its nuclear arsenal much faster than anticipated, saying Beijing could have 700 warheads by 2027 and possibly 1,000 by 20

column2: The drones hit speeds in excess of 100 kilometres per hour during the contest.

column2: The bikes are typically three-wheeled and low to the ground, meaning that not all trails can cater for the riders with a disability. But in WA that's starting to change.

column1: Cleo Smith's case touched the nation. But not all missing children's cases will have the same outcome

column2: Italy's culture minister, Dario Franceschini, says the find is an "important discovery" that enriches knowledge of "the level of society still little known".

column1: Tourism pressure mounts on Tasmanian government to end native forest logging

column1: NSW COVID-19 vaccination data reveals which areas are lagging

column1: How slapping solar on the MCG could help Melbourne to net zero
column2: With Australia committing to net zero, a study has found central Melbourne could meet most of its energy needs with rooftop solar on skyscrapers and big public buildings like the MCG.

column1: One reason 2022 looks like an ideal time for a government to land re-election

column1: 'Data entry error' caused vaccine report mistake, TGA says

column1: How did China's 'anti-Valentine's Day' turn into the world's biggest shopping event?

column1: Lukashenko accused of 'inhuman, gangster-style approach' to migrants

column1: Knife-wielding man shot dead by Norwegian police

column1: Private security could soon guard secretive naval communications base instead of AFP

column1: The deadly new risk Afghan women face: It starts with a strange phone call and can end with murder

column1: Schools can still expel LGBTQ+ kids. The Religious Discrimination Bill only makes it worse

column2: As a Senate inquiry looks into the collapse of the Sterling Group housing scheme, some of the elderly victims are now finding themselves homeless.

column1: Victorian government dismisses 'blackmail' claims from Djokovic's dad over Aus Open vaccine mandate
column2: Victorian Sports Minister Martin Pakula rejects claims by Novak Djokovic's dad that Australian Open organisers are forcing players to get vaccinated against COVID-19.

column1: 'It's beyond wicked': Farmer blasts energy authority, Powercor after St Patrick's Day bushfire backdown
column2: Jill Porter lost half her dairy herd when bushfires tore through south-west Victoria. Now, she wants someone to be held to account so other families are spared such trauma.

column1: Space junk has forced NASA to temporarily postpone a spacewalk. So where did it come from?
column2: NASA is forced to temporarily postpone a spacewalk because of space junk that could puncture an astronaut's suit or damage the International Space Station.

column1: Backpacker tells inquest Theo Hayez didn't appear drunk on the night he disappeared in Byron Bay
column2: Inquest hears the missing backpacker was sober enough to talk about European politics before Google searching a small village seldom known to tourists.

column1: 'We don't want them walking the streets': Morcombe family welcomes tougher child killer parole laws
column2: Queensland Parliament last night passed legislation that could see the "worst of the worst" kept behind bars for decades after their parole date.

column1: Lady Jane in Spain: The Australian mango enjoying sweet success internationally
column2: It was developed near Katherine in the NT, but there are now commercial plantings of this mango in Spain and trials underway in more than 10 countries.

column1: Scientists identify armoured dinosaur with tail like Aztec weapon
column2: The Stegouros elengassen is a four-legged creature which lived in what is now South America's southernmost tip during the Cretaceous Period.

column1: We can't stop workplace sexual harassment without banning non-disclosure agreements
column2: NDAs are increasingly used against employees who make complaints about discrimination and harassment. But the practice has a chilling effect on people's willingness to speak out, and must be eradicated, write Maria O'Sullivan and Judith Bessant.

column1: Drought, a mouse plague and now La Niña — but is that good or bad news for farmers?
column2: Even though Australia has just had its wettest November in more than two decades, some farmers are still waiting.

column1: Claire quit her job and sold her possessions — then Omicron changed everything
column2: Claire Ebersohn was only two days away from starting her new life in Australia but global panic over the Omicron strain of COVID-19 has locked her out of the country.

column1: Jennifer visited a museum and saw her own heart on display
column2: The history of medical transplants stretches back millennia and includes some bizarre and gruesome milestones.

column1: Was it a bear, or an early human? Mystery of 3.7-million-year-old footprints solved
column2: Around 3.7 million years ago, a metre-high early human gingerly walked across the slippery ground in what is now Tanzania. But what species were they?

column1: Twitter's new Indian-American CEO highlights corporate Australia's lack of cultural diversity
column2: American technology giants including Twitter, Google, Microsoft and IBM are among American companies promoting people of Indian origin to CEO. But in Australia, it is rare for top publicly listed company chiefs to come from culturally diverse backgrounds, Nassim Khadem writes.

column1: Wealthy nations starved the developing world of vaccines. Omicron shows the cost of this greed
column2: The new variant is a warning: unless we take urgent action to correct global vaccine inequities, we risk the emergence of further variants, some of which may evade vaccines.

column1: 'Significant momentum': How some super funds become more profitable by investing sustainably
column2: A new study shows Australian superannuation funds that invest responsibly are becoming increasingly profitable than traditional funds. But some analyst says they need to be more transparent.

column1: World War II bomb explodes near Munich's main train station, injuring four
column2: A World War II bomb explodes on a construction site near a busy train station in central Munich, injuring four people.

column1: Historic laws to ban hackers, human rights abusers and possibly Putin's cronies from Australia
column2: The legislation, partly based on the United States Magnitsky Act, allows the federal government to sanction people who engage in "egregious conduct" and could see cyber hackers, rights abusers and corrupt officials banned from Australia.

column1: SA parliament goes into COVID-19 shutdown to allow contact tracing after former premier tests positive
column2: South Australia's parliament will be adjourned on Thursday morning, and all MPs and staff directed to avoid in-person meetings, after former premier Jay Weatherill tested positive for COVID-19.

column1: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill tests positive for COVID-19
column2: Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill has tested positive for COVID-19 after attending an event on Saturday where other cases were present.

column1: Operation Ironside nets 18 more suspects as police seize guns and drugs
column2: The latest arrests come amid a wave of SA Police raids across Adelaide, with guns seized and six properties searched in relation to what police described as drug trafficking and money laundering activities.

column1: Two young men sentenced to four years in jail over fatal hit-and-run in Alice Springs
column2: A judge says a man aged 20 and a boy aged 16 had shown a "selfish disregard" for the safety of other road users in their actions after a hit-and-run last year that left a 47-year-old man dead.

column1: Young woman was stabbed by own family because she was dating man of another faith, court told
column2: A 21-year-old woman stabbed in an Adelaide suburban shopping centre car park on Tuesday morning was attacked and ambushed by members of her own family because she was dating someone outside her faith, a court hears.

column1: The Loop: Hunt and Porter quit politics, man dies in Qld floods, world's most expensive city named
column2: Get yourself in The Loop with a speedy wrap of today's news.

column1: COVID case visited major Gold Coast shopping centre on Black Friday
column2: The city is on high alert as Queensland Health confirms a new positive COVID case went to Robina Town Centre last week.

column1: Queensland's drenching to continue over summer, following record-breaking November
column2: Monthly rainfall records tumble across Queensland with some places recording the wettest November they've seen in more than 100 years.

column1: Woman dies in hospital days after going missing on Tiwi Islands
column2: A 35-year-old woman dies in Royal Darwin Hospital, days after she went missing on the Tiwi Islands and was found stranded in mangroves.

column1: The father of missing Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez storms out of coronial inquest
column2: The father of missing Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez has stormed out of a coronial inquest in Byron Bay, as security guards give evidence about evicting his son.

column1: US white supremacists targeting under-vaxxed Aboriginal communities, WA Premier says
column2: Mark McGowan says American hate groups are specifically targeting remote Aboriginal communities by spreading misinformation about COVID-19 vaccinations.

column1: NSW Police officer found guilty of perjury for lying about girlfriend's fake rape claim
column2: A NSW police officer who helped his girlfriend fabricate a rape claim is found guilty of perjury.

column1: Minister calls for Shandee Blackburn murder inquiry to reopen
column2: "It can't be left the way it is": The mother of murdered woman Shandee Blackburn welcomed the Minister's comments, a week after forensic results came under the spotlight.

column1: 'So missed by all of us': Family of man believed to have been killed by Adelaide drug dealers speak
column2: The family of a man believed to have been killed by Adelaide drug dealers speak of the grief and pain they have experienced since he was last seen on December 19 last year.

column1: 'You can't hate yourself into being better': The misconception around feeling guilt versus shame
column2: Research professor Brené Brown has spent a large part of her career looking at shame, which she says has now become an epidemic in society. So how can we better deal with our feelings?

column1: NSW man's alleged $5,000 rampage in Tasmanian COVID quarantine hotel
column2: A New South Wales man who flew into Tasmania then allegedly refused to leave and caused $5,000 worth of damage to his hotel quarantine room is sent packing by police.

column1: After three court trials, a man has been jailed over a shooting in Canberra's south
column2: The juries in Christopher Cunningham's first two trials were dismissed, and the third trial had already been running for seven days when Cunningham agreed to plead guilty.

column1: If you think this is rats jumping off a sinking political ship, think again
column2: The departure of some of the nation's most high-profile Liberal politicians on the eve of an election easily lends itself to the suggestion of rats fleeing a sinking ship. But as the last poll showed, it's not over until the votes are cast, writes political correspondent Brett Worthington.

column1: WA Premier Mark McGowan flags tighter South Australia border as government seeks 'urgent' health advice
column2: The West Australian border with South Australia looks to be toughened as early as this afternoon after 18 COVID-19 cases are detected in Adelaide in the space of 24 hours.

column1: Widow of man paralysed on 69th birthday says NDIS threshold has 'got to be fixed'
column2: Both major parties have been accused of "shameful" inaction over the NDIS age cut-off. Now, advocates are fighting to make it a federal election issue.

column1: PM accuses Labor of 'disgraceful slur' over Home Affairs contract awarded to two close friends
column2: Scott Morrison hits back at any suggestion he had a role in the Home Affairs Department awarding an almost $80,000 contract to a company run by two of his closest friends.

column1: Surgeon fined in Austria for amputating wrong leg, judge awards damages to widow of patient
column2: The surgeon marked the wrong leg of her 82-year-old patient, who died before the case came to court.

column1: Big bank mortgages below 2 per cent going, going, gone
column2: Mortgages from the big four banks with a '1' in front of the interest rate are now a thing of the past, while investors take over as the drivers of lending and property price growth.

column1: 'We hear your voice, and we will listen': Task force recommends staged approach to criminalising coercive control in Queensland
column2: The approach would include public education, an implementation plan to prepare for criminalisation in 2024 and co-designing a strategy to address the over-representation of First Nations people in the criminal justice system before the legislation is introduced.

column1: Man accused of helping to kidnap Stuart MacGill was a bikie on parole, court told
column2: A man accused of involvement in the alleged kidnapping of former cricketer Stuart MacGill was on parole at the time and is allegedly an affiliate of the Comanchero motorcycle gang, a Sydney court has heard.

column1: 'It's just wrecked everything': Inglewood begins massive flood clean-up
column2: Residents in the southern Queensland border town of Inglewood start the clean-up after floodwaters inundated homes and businesses.
column3: Georgie Hewson, Jon Daly, and Anthea Moodie

column1: AFL legend Ron Barassi tests positive for COVID-19
column2: The 85-year-old will miss taking part in Melbourne's long-awaited AFL premiership celebrations at the MCG on Sunday.
column3: Georgie Hewson, Jon Daly, and Anthea Moodie

column1: Greg Hunt confirms he's retiring from politics at the next election
column2: Federal Health and Aged Care Minister Greg Hunt announces he will retire at the next election and not recontest his seat in Victoria.

column1: The $35 hardware in your home that could cost you $14,000
column2: There's a hidden flood risk in your home and it has absolutely nothing to do with the rain, or your drains. But it could cost you tens of thousands of dollars if you don't sort it out.

column1: Victorian government's pandemic bill set to become law after passing upper house
column2: After weeks of negotiations and substantial amendments, the Victorian government's controversial pandemic legislation has cleared its last hurdle.

column1: Scores of protesters demand a drink at 'freedom pub' after anti-vax licensee convicted
column2: Demonstrators waved placards decrying "tyranny" and called for "justice" outside Singleton Court. Inside, Bradley John Hill's matter was dealt with in five minutes.

column1: Mum threatened at knifepoint with children in car
column2: Police allege the woman parked her Range Rover station wagon at her Klemzig home around 3:20pm yesterday and was approached by a man armed with a knife.

column1: 'Explanation needed' after teenagers' escape from Howard Springs quarantine, NT opposition says
column2: After two escapes in a number of days, the NT opposition is renewing calls for the federal government to resume control of Darwin's main quarantine facility.

column1: Everything you need to know about the Bathurst 1000
column2: This year's Supercars season concludes on the mountain at the Bathurst 1000 this weekend. Here's everything you need to know ahead of the great race around Mount Panorama, including its later start time.

column1: Higher prices predicted for watermelons, chilli after torrential rain destroys summer crops
column2: Australians are set to pay a premium for popular summer produce, with widespread storms destroying crops across Queensland. Some growers say the deluge has wiped out up to 85 per cent of their crops.

column1: Queenslanders in for a brief reprieve before more flooding set to hit sodden southern Queensland
column2: As floodwaters recede and residents across southern Queensland clean up, the weather bureau warns isolated storms across already sodden catchment areas could lead to more flooding next week.

column1: Elective surgery patients in Queensland may require COVID test
column2: Elective surgery patients may require a negative COVID-19 test in the 72 hours before their procedures under options being discussed within Queensland Health to reduce the risk of hospital transmission.

column1: 'People not heeding our advice': Some Tasmanians stuck in floodwaters as storms strike
column2: Hobartians are mopping up this morning following thunderstorms that brought heavy rain and hail to the Tasmanian capital and parts of the state's south-east.

column1: There were winners, losers and big losers amongst Australia's universities last year — and the 'big eight' didn't escape
column2: Some universities actually increased revenue once the pandemic started, yet some vice-chancellors are deeply unhappy. The reasons why are complex, writes Conor Duffy.

column1: Nathan was once told he'd never run his own business — now he's doing it with the support of a major corporate
column2: When Nathan Johnston was younger, people told him he was "dreaming" when he talked about starting his own business. But on International Day of People with Disability it becomes a reality, as he launches a social media platform he created from his dining room table.

column1: Friday News Quiz: Rhianna, Trump and Katter were in the headlines this week. Only one was kicked out a bar
column2: Will you be declared a national hero for your efforts or will you be unceremoniously thrown out? Test yourself to find out.

column1: 'Moving towards COVID-normal': ACT to overhaul state of emergency laws, but don't expect Victorian-style protests
column2: The ACT government says it will soon be hard to justify calling the ongoing pandemic a public health "emergency", and wants to move away from that language.

column1: Rachelle Miller says she made her allegations about Alan Tudge not for revenge, but so that other women can be heard
column2: It took a bruising year after Rachelle Miller first told her story about minister Alan Tudge for her to finally be heard, and for him to face consequences and stand aside, writes Louise Milligan.

column1: An eight-hour year and hot enough to melt iron — this planet's 'not somewhere you'd want to go on holidays'
column2: About 30 light-years away a rocky planet as dense as pure iron orbits a red dwarf star half the size of our Sun. A year on GJ 367 b is shorter than a day on Earth.

column1: Germany considers COVID-19 vaccine mandate as cases surge
column2: Germany bans unvaccinated people from non-essential stores and venues, and considers making vaccines mandatory as new case numbers hit 70,000 in 24 hours.

column1: Satellites have discovered huge cloud of undisclosed methane emissions over Australia, experts say
column2: Methane is a powerful, invisible gas that might be a key driver of global warming. Now satellite imagery is raising questions over whether Australia has been accurately reporting its emissions to international bodies.

column1: Myanmar junta cancels passports of high-profile opponents and shadow government figures
column2: Myanmar's military junta revokes the passports of dozens of its leading opponents in an apparent attempt to stop them travelling and building international opposition to the regime.

column1: SA has opened it borders to COVID, what can Tasmania learn from it?
column2: South Australia is a little over a week into reopening their borders and what happens with COVID-19 infections — and the death rate — is being watched closely by Tasmania, where the island state is soon to open up to the world.

column1: People in NSW have to vote tomorrow — this is what you need to know
column2: Almost every NSW resident has to vote in one of the more than 120 elections set to be held tomorrow. This is what you need to know.

column1: Eye-opening moments in the classroom remind me why teaching is my dream job
column2: I want to change negative perspectives and misconceptions about disability that I have faced my whole life. And already I've had so many special, eye-opening moments in the classroom that remind me I'm on the right path, writes Ashleigh Gibson.

column1: If solar is now so cheap, why is my power bill still so high?
column2: After years of increases, power prices are set to fall, thanks largely to cheap solar. So how cheap can solar get? And what does this mean for your electricity bill?

column1: Omicron has again disrupted travel plans, but one country is pushing ahead with its quarantine-free experiment
column2: Fiji has pushed to get its vaccination rate to more than 90 per cent and has come up with a model for international travel that requires travellers to stay in the same place for a few days, but also feels nothing like quarantine.

column1: Patty Mills becomes first basketballer to take home Don Award
column2: Patty Mills is setting franchise records for the Brooklyn Nets in the NBA but leading the Boomers to an Olympic medal has helped him to claim on of Australian sports' top honours.

column1: Health Minister 'disappointed' at being kept in the dark over detection of Legionella bacteria at Perth hospital
column2: A detection of Legionella bacteria at Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital in Perth leads to 16 rooms being treated for the bacteria and two patients receiving precautionary antibiotics, as the Health Minister criticises health executives over a failure to communicate.

column1: Meghan wins court battle with British tabloid that published private letter to her father
column2: The decision spares the Duchess of Sussex from having to appear at a trial in which her estranged father Thomas Markle would also have given evidence.

column1: 'We have concerns': US slams China's hypersonic weapons tests
column2: Beijing's efforts to accelerate its military capabilities were highlighted by its July test of a hypersonic weapon, capable of partially orbiting the Earth before re-entering the atmosphere and gliding on a manoeuvrable path to its target.

column1: Supercars veteran eyeing first Bathurst 1000 crown
column2: Lee Holdsworth — who is partnered with Chaz Mostert — is allowing himself to dream of a maiden Bathurst 1000 win in his 18th attempt.

column1: The Loop: Tudge stands aside, Australia's eighth Omicron case, Spotify Wrapped releases 'audio auras' and why shame isn't helpful
column2: Here's your TL;DR for today's news.
